prompt: What is the legal standard for the Subsequent Medical Treatment or Aid?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The term \"subsequent\" means following or succeeding. The term, \"in aid of the right\" means \"in furtherance of\" or \"in promotion of\" the right. Therefore, subsequent medical treatment or aid to a right means medical treatment or aid which furthers the use of that right. Some examples of what would be upheld as subsequent treatment or aid to a right is to increase or restore the range of motion of a knee that is arthritic or to transplant a kidney following the loss of a kidney from kidney disease. An example of what would not be considered subsequent treatment or aid to a right would be an operation to remove cataracts which would not restore a prior state but rather improve the condition of an eye that is affected only by natural deterioration.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The legal standard for subsequent medical treatment or aid involves the conditions and obligations that apply after medical treatment has been provided to an injured person. This may include follow-up treatments, rehabilitation, physical therapy, mental health counseling, and prescription medications or devices necessary for the recovery or health maintenance of the injured individual. Conditions may include the timing and frequency of treatments, locations where treatments are to be provided, the type and extent of treatments, and the qualified healthcare professionals authorized to provide such treatments. Obligations may also include financial responsibilities, documentation requirements, and cooperation from the injured individual to comply with the prescribed medical treatment plan. The specifics often depend on applicable laws, insurance policies, or agreements related to the injury or medical care.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In Florida, the person who is injured in an accident is entitled to recover the reasonable value of subsequent medical help that is a necessary consequence of the accident or injury. This may include rehabilitation. The person who caused the accident only has to pay for the necessary medical treatment. The other person is responsible for paying for any optional treatment or treatment for any condition which is unrelated to the accident. Although the person who caused the accident must pay for any medical treatment necessary as a result of the accident, there is no guarantee that insurance companies will honor that obligation. It depends on the insurance coverage that the person who caused the accident has. You can call toll-free and leave an English or Spanish message. You should give us your name and phone number. prompt: What are the elements of the Mitigation of Damages (Personal Injury)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These are the elements of the cause of action. The plaintiff in a lawsuit must prove all of these elements to win the lawsuit.    - The plaintiff filed a lawsuit to recover for a loss.    - In a timely way, the plaintiff did what was reasonable to keep the loss from getting worse. For example, the plaintiff tried to prevent further injuries or complications to an injury.    - The plaintiff failed to do those reasonable things to prevent the loss from getting worse.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These are the elements of the cause of action. The first element of mitigation of damages is that the injured person must have suffered damages. The second element is that the injured person took actions to reduce the damages. For example, in a personal injury case, you must accept a job paying minimum wage in order to mitigate your damages. Alternatively, you must show that it was impossibly for you to take actions to reduce the damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of a claim for mitigation of damages are as follows: 1. the injured party has a duty to mitigate damages; 2. the injured party breaches the duty; and 3. harm results.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of a mitigation of damages defense for a personal injury claim may include the following steps:       - Showing the plaintiff was under a duty to mitigate - The plaintiff must show that he or she acted reasonably to limit the damages caused by the injury.    - Proving the plaintiff failed to mitigate damages - If the plaintiff was under a duty to mitigate damages and fails to express that duty, the defendant may be able to mitigate damages by showing that some damages caused by the injury could have been avoided if the plaintiff acted reasonably.       Each state may have slightly different requirements.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The plaintiff in a personal injury case has a duty to minimize the damages he claims to have suffered. This is called the duty to mitigate or reduce damages. prompt: What are the elements of the Mitigation of Damages (Property Damage)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of mitigation of damages are not explicitly set forth in case law. Under case law, the failure to mitigate damages is an affirmative defense. Therefore, a party wishing to claim that the opposing party has failed to mitigate must generally raise the defense in the pleadings and prove the best mitigation that could have been done. Although elements are not expressly set forth, under general contract principles, the defendant would have to prove: (1) the plaintiff had the opportunity to adopt money saving measures with respect to the damaged property; (2) the best practicable measures that plaintiff could have done with respect to the property; and (3) that by not adopting such measures, the plaintiff was able to keep his damages at a higher level than they would have been had the measures been adopted.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"There are ten elements of mitigation, which the defendant must prove by a preponderance of the evidence:       - Knowledge of the breach;     - An opportunity to mitigate damages;     - The ability to mitigate damages;     - A duty to mitigate damages;     - Mitigation by reasonable efforts and expense;     - Proportionality between the costs of mitigation and the damages avoided;     - Reasonable efforts need not be successful;     - The injured party need not risk his or her life or health;     - The injured party need not sacrifice his or her personal tastes; and     - Contributory negligence is not a defense.        The injured party may not recover damages for loss that he or she could have avoided by reasonable efforts. The defendant however has the burden to prove that the injured party failed to mitigate damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These are the elements of mitigation of damages:         - If you promise to rent an apartment from your landlord, you breach the lease, and then you move into an apartment across town, your landlord must lower the amount of the \"damages\" by whatever he or she is able to recover from renting your apartment to someone else until the original lease ends. This is called mitigation of damages. Mitigation of damages only applies to certain types of contracts (such as leases) and certain types of damages (such as rent or salary).    - To be entitled to a credit for the amount received, the payment must result from efforts to mitigate, or lessen, the damages caused by the breach.    - Any amount credited as a set-off, has to be actual money (such as rent or salary). An amount deducted based on speculation (such as the anticipated cost of a future sale) or that effectively amounts to a withholding or delay is not a credit.        The property in the apartment you moved from, in the example above, is not damaged property and the duties on part of the landlord (or the person who breached the lease in that example) regarding mitigation are limited to finding one or more tenants to rent the apartment.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What are the elements that the claimant must prove? The claimant (plaintiff) must prove the following elements to prevail on a claim for mitigation of damages: 1. A duty to mitigate; 2. Failure to mitigate; and 3. Reasonableness of mitigation.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of mitigation of damages are (1) knowledge of the circumstances giving rise to the breach; (2) a reasonable opportunity to avoid or reduce damages; and (3) a failure to reasonably avoid or reduce the damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Damages From Multiple Defendants?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When two or more persons, including corporations, commit a tort, the injured party can sue one, some or all of them. The injured party must show that each defendant breached a standard of conduct, that there was a causal connection between the defendant's conduct and the harm to the plaintiff, and that the harm to the plaintiff is not too remote. Fault may be apportioned among multiple defendants.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If more than one person acted negligently and caused you harm, you may sue more than one person. When two or more people are sued together, this is called a joint lawsuit or a joining of defendants. The defendants can be joined (1) in the same lawsuit or (2) in separate lawsuits.    One kind of joint lawsuit occurs when each defendant could be held responsible for all of the damages. In that case, if you do not collect the full amount of your damages from one defendant, you can try to collect the rest from another defendant. Once you receive all your damages, you cannot sue any other defendants.     When you sue two or more people in the same lawsuit, you sue them as joint defendants. When one of the persons responsible is acting through his or her employer, your employer is also usually joined in the lawsuit. For example, if someone took a truck from work and caused an accident, you might sue the driver and the driver's employer together in one law suit.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If more than one person may be legally responsible for your injury, you may be able to try to get damages from each one. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Each defendant is individually responsible for all harm caused by the defendant, even if the plaintiff has recovered damages from other defendants involved.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When there is more than one person who is legally responsible for your injury, you can have a separate claim against each of them.    For example, if you are in a car accident that was your car dealer's fault but also the fault of the person who sold your car's previous safety inspection, you may have a claim against both. You can sue both or just one. Even if you sue only one, however, it is a good idea to keep your claim against the other one.    If you sue all of those responsible, you can ask for a jury trial to decide if each one was responsible and if so, how responsible. As between the ones who caused the injury, there can be a question of whether they should be found jointly (together) or severally (separately) liable. If they are jointly liable, it means that they are liable together and that you can recover all the money you are owed from any one of the defendants, even if that person paid more than his or her share. If they are severally liable, it means that each person's share of the damages is separate, and you cannot recover more from one defendant than the determined share of liability.     If you sue only one of those responsible or if you sue some and not all, the one you sue might ask the court to dismiss some or all of the claim against him or her. Whether the claim against him or her survives will depend on the laws of your state.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are the elements of the Damages on Multiple Legal Theories?

However, especially if actions at law and suits in equity are both involved, it is also fairly common that a party is prevented from recovering more than once for the same injury.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How should a jury apply Prejudgment Interest (Civ. Code, Â§ 3288)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When there has been a detriment caused to a person by the breach of an obligation not arising from contract, and if the amount of damages for the breach is capable of pecuniary estimation, the person who has been so damaged is entitled to recover from the person who breached the obligation a sum that will constitute fair compensation for the loss or damage sustained, which sum may include an amount to compensate for the loss of use of money and that is called prejudice to the person while the obligation has remained unsatisfied.    In this case, it is claimed that the obligation breached does not arise from contract. If you find that a detriment was caused to a person by the breach; that the amount of damages for the breach can be determined by a money value; and that person has suffered loss or damage, then that person is entitled to fair compensation. Part of that compensation may be an amount to cover the loss of use of the money between the time the obligation became unsatisfied and the time of payment.    You must honor such entitlement if you find that it applies. If it applies, the amount to compensate for the loss of use of the money is called prejudgment interest.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The statute on prejudgment interest provides that if you render a verdict for money damages on breach of a contract or for injury for which property damages are an element of damages, and the damages are certain or capable of being made certain by calculation, you must award prejudgment interest on the damages. The statutory rate of interest is 10 percent, unless the parties agreed on a different rate.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The statute provides that if you find in favor of a plaintiff on a contract claim, that plaintiff is entitled to interest on the award of damages, from the time damages are sustained to the time of judgment. If the defendant proves these facts by a preponderance of the evidence, you must reduce the interest award by the amount of the reduction.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A \"prejudgment interest award\" is an order that you pay interest for a period before the start of a lawsuit. prompt: What is the legal standard for the Punitive Damagesâ€”Individual Defendantâ€”Trial Not Bifurcated?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The legal standard for the calculation of punitive damages, in federal court, is based on the Supreme Courts decisions in BMW of North America, Inc. v. Gore and State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. v. Campbell. In State Farm, the Supreme Court indicated that courts should consider three guideposts for determining whether the punitive damages award is reasonable and comensurate to the actual malice of the defendant: (1) the degree of reprehensibility of a defendant's misconduct; (2) the disparity between the actual or potential harm suffered by the plaintiff and the punitive damages award; and (3) the difference between the punitive damages awarded by the jury and the civil penalties authorized or imposed in comparable cases. In BMW and State Farm, the Supreme Court also indicated that it is improper for punitive damages to be grossly excessive and that ratios ranging from a single-digit multiplier to a maximum of four to one are generally appropriate. In Alaska Airlines, Inc. v. Brock, 480 U.S. 678, 684 (1987), the Supreme Court held that \"the very notion of punitive damages presumes and calls for discretion on the part of the trier of fact\"; however, Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 59(e) allows courts to alter or amend a judgment to consider whether a jury's punitive damage award was excessive. Punitive damages are limited in actions arising under federal civil rights statutes. 42 U.S.C. 1981a(b)(3) limits punitive damages to $300,000, if the employer has more than 500 employees; $50,000 if the employer has more than 100, but not more than 500 employees; and $10,000 if the employer has at least 15, but not more than 100 employees. A party seeking to appeal a district court's decision on punitive damages must first obtain permission to appeal, the so-called interlocutory appeal. 28 U.S.C. 1292(a)(2).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"District courts and courts of appeals use different standards of review when considering whether to uphold a punitive damage award. A district court acts as a gatekeeper between the jury and the court of appeals and employs a two-step test to determine whether it must grant a remittitur or new trial. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The principle of Punitive Damagesâ€”Entity Defendantâ€”Trial Not Bifurcated states that a plaintiff may seek punitive damages under certain circumstances. Punitive damages are awarded against a defendant in addition to other damages. Their purpose is to punish the defendant for extreme misconduct and to discourage others from engaging in similar behavior.    Where an entity defendant (for example, a corporation) is alleged to act with a certain state of mind, the state of mind of the specific employee must usually be shown. For example, where it is alleged that the entity acted recklessly in exposing the plaintiff to a harmful substance, the reckless state of mind of the employee who exposed the plaintiff must be shown.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"This principle is part of the ALI Principles of the Law of Aggregate Litigation. Part 3: Aggregate Actions. Chapter 2: Aggregation Devices. Section 2.11: Punitive Damagesâ€”Entity Defendantâ€”Trial Not Bifurcated.    If a defendant is a corporation, limited liability company, or other \"entity,\" whether or not the purpose of its formation is profit, there generally is a good case management reason to avoid bifurcation of an aggregate action. \"Bifurcation\" means dividing the trial into two parts. In the first part, there is a determination of liability. In the second part, there is a determination of damages. Among the kinds of damages that may be at issue are punitive damages. Punitive damages punish or deter egregious, intentional and malicious wrongdoing, fraud, or malice.    In bifurcated trials, inconsistent verdicts frequently occur with respect to compensatory damages and punitive damages. Evidence that is relevant for a portion of the trial, for example, on compensatory damages, may make a jury angry. Continued exposure to that evidence in the punitive damages portion of the trial increases risk of an excessive punitive damages verdict. If the evidence is excluded during the compensatory damages portion of the trial, it may increase risk of inconsistent verdicts. Comprehensive regulation is needed to reduce inconsistent verdicts.    In multiparty litigation, ruling on punitive damages on a defendant-by-defendant basis generally increases the risk of inconsistent verdicts in triers of fact than if the determination is made on a group basis. Comprehensive regulation is needed to reduce inconsistent verdicts.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The principle of Punitive Damages-Entity Defendant-Trial Not Bifurcated provides that a trial may not be split, or bifurcated, into two parts for the purpose of deciding on punitive damages against an entity defendant. prompt: What is the jury instruction for Punitive Damagesâ€”Individual and Corporate Defendants (Corporate Liability Based on Acts of Named Individual)â€”Bifurcated Trial (Second Phase)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Punitive Damages--Individual and Corporate Defendants (Corporate Liability Based on Acts of Named Individual)--Bifurcated Trial (Second Phase)       The plaintiff claims that (name of individual) acted with malice, oppression or fraud. Malice, oppression or fraud means:        1. malice - conduct which is sufficient to excite, in the mind of an average, reasonable person, a feeling of hatred, disgust, or contempt for the plaintiff; or an intent to cause injury to the plaintiff;        2. oppression - subjecting a person to cruel and unjust hardship in conscious disregard of that persons rights; or placing a person in a state of hardship or adversity, giving rise to a just claim for damages; or        3. fraud - an intentional misrepresentation, deceit, or concealment of a material fact known to the defendant with the intention on the part of the defendant of thereby depriving a person of his or her legal rights or otherwise causing injury; which representation, deceit or concealment is relied upon by the plaintiff to his or her detriment.         In order to recover punitive damages, the plaintiff must prove by clear and convincing evidence that (name of individual) acted with malice, oppression or fraud.    You are instructed that your finding on punitive damages cannot be based on speculation, guess, or conjecture.     As to a corporate defendant, before you may award punitive damages, you must find by clear and convincing evidence that the relevant conduct or a relevant omission preceded, followed, or was concurrent with:        1. an express authorization, consent or ratification of the conduct or omission by an officer or managing agent of the corporation;        2. a reckless indifference to the interests of the plaintiff and an awareness by an officer or managing agent of the corporation that the corporation has such indifference; or        3. an intent by an officer or managing agent of the corporation to benefit the corporation even if the officer or managing agent acted for an improper purpose.    The plaintiff seeks punitive damages from (name of defendant). As you consider the amount of punitive damages to be awarded, if any, you may consider the following factors:        1. the character of the conduct involved;        2. the nature and extent of the harm to the plaintiff that the defendant caused or intended to cause; and        3. the wealth of the defendant.    Report of the Supreme Court Committee on Standard Jury Instructions in Civil Cases. Oklahoma City: Supreme Court Committee on Standard Jury Instructions in Civil Cases.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In the second phase of the trial, you will decide whether punitive damages are appropriate. Punitive damages may be awarded to punish a defendant and to deter the defendant and others from acting in the same way in the future. The purpose of punitive damages is not to compensate for the plaintiff's injuries.    For each defendant against whom you awarded compensatory damages in the first phase, you must decide whether punitive damages are appropriate. You may award punitive damages only if you find, by clear and convincing evidence, that the defendant acted with malice or oppression. Malice means you've found that defendant acted with intent to cause injury or with a reckless disregard of the plaintiff's rights or safety. Oppression means you've found that defendant acted with a wrongful act done knowingly, with the recognition or the condition of the plaintiff's rights and with a consciousness that such act was an interference with those rights.    If you determine that punitive damages are appropriate, you must determine the amount. In determining the amount of punitive damages, you may consider any evidence you found relevant to the amount of compensatory damages and any of the following factors:       -  the nature of the act that caused the harm, including whether it involved a reckless disregard for the health or safety of any person;     - the degree of reprehensibility of the act committed by the defendant;     -  the duration of the act and whether the act was an isolated event or part of a pattern of conduct;     -  the amount of compensatory damages awarded;     -  the wealth of the defendant; and     -  the ability of the defendant to pay punitive damages.       You may not consider any payment in settlement of an action before you have reached a verdict.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Comparative fault is a legal concept which reduces damages owed to a plaintiff in proportion to any fault that may be found to be on the part of that same plaintiff. For example, if the plaintiff was 30% at fault and damages are fixed at $100,000, then the damages the plaintiff can collect are reduced by 30% to $70,000. This instruction is not intended for use in cases involving \"modified comparative fault.\" Under modified comparative fault, if the plaintiff's fault equals or exceeds that of the total amount of fault attributed to the defendants, the law will not impose any liability on the part of the defendants. Comparative Fault of Plaintiff - General Verdict    If you find that the defendant was negligent and that the negligence was a cause of harm, you must then decide whether the plaintiff was also negligent and, if so, how that negligence affected the plaintiff's recovery. \"Negligence\" means failing to use reasonable care under all the circumstances.    For example, if you find that the plaintiff was one-half responsible for the harm suffered, you must reduce the plaintiff's damages by one-half.    You should also remember that the fact that a person is partially at fault for an injury does not bar recovery in total.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The following United States federal appellate courts have held that evidence of comparative fault should be admitted into the record even if the jury returns only a general verdict: Seventh Circuit: Apart from its effect on damages, a finding of comparative fault does not negate any essential element of a claim. Therefore, in the absence of an express provision of law to the contrary, the law of the case doctrine does not bar courts from admitting evidence of relative fault into the record when only a general verdict is requested. Additionally, the parties may expressly agree to submit only a general verdict to the jury. If parties waive their rights to a special verdict, a court must accept the waiver; otherwise, a trial judge would be empowered to overrule the parties' waiver and force them to use the special verdict form. However, a court has discretion whether to grant instruction on comparative fault, especially if it would involve a complicated jury instruction. It also has discretion regarding the allocation of fault among the defendants. Fayette County, IL v. City of Chicago, IL, 824 F.2d 1127, 1131-1134 (7th Cir. 1987) (internal citations omitted). Fifth Circuit: It is well-settled that a district court must grant a jury instruction on comparative fault if the party requesting the instruction shows (1) that the theory of comparative fault is a cognizable defense and (2) that there was sufficient evidence for a reasonable juror to find comparative fault. If a jury instruction on comparative fault is granted, the plaintiff must be given an opportunity to respond to the defense of comparative fault, whether that is through a responsive jury instruction or a new trial. Hall v. City of W. Palm Beach, 266 F.3d 1364, 1370-1371 (11th Cir. 2001) (internal citations omitted); Torres-Darden v. City of Dothan, 803 F. Supp. 1455, 1463 (M.D. Ala. 1992), aff'd, 973 F.2d 690 (11th Cir. 1992).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you are awarded damages for past lost earnings, it is generally assumed that you have made reasonable efforts to mitigate those damages. This means that if you could have reduced your lost earnings by accepting alternative work, even if it was less desirable, you must show that you in fact did take that work, or that there was a good reason you did not. By refusing to accept any suitable alternative employment, you may risk reducing the damages award.Ã¢Â€Â”Produce Marine Corp. v. United States, 378 F.3d 1346, 1353-54 (Fed. Cir. 2004); see DRAM Specialties v. The Home Depot, 263 F.3d 1338, 1345-47 (Fed. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Like damages for future lost earnings, past damages are not recoverable for loss that could have been avoided if the plaintiff had \"used reasonable means to avoid or reduce the damages\", i.e., to mitigate the damages. For example, the plaintiff injured by defendant's tort may not recover lost earnings before the trial if his or her condition would have improved or ended by then if he or she had sought or followed medical treatment. Skills Training Defines Reasonable Opportunity. Reasonable opportunity to mitigate damages includes opportunity to acquire appropriate training to enable the plaintiff to seek other employment. Thus, the plaintiff is expected to make a reasonable effort to mitigate the damages. Without the effort, the damages may be reduced or denied.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you hire an employee and then fire her, she can sue you for wrongful discharge. If she does, damages will likely include her lost wages. If you are found liable for her lost wages and you have proof that she was able to find another job, then your damages may be reduced. The courts may reduce your damages by the amount of wages that she could earn in the other job. This means that the judge will consider that she has the duty to mitigate her damages by seeking and accepting a comparable job.     The idea of mitigating damages also applies to other types of damages.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you are injured in a car accident, your future lost earnings could include the wages you would have earned if you could have continued working until you retired.  For example, a 30-year-old construction worker who was injured in a car accident might have a lifetime of lost earnings to claim, if she could not work from the day of the accident until she reached the normal retirement age.  On the other hand, a 64-year-old worker would normally only have about a year or less of lost earnings.  Thus, a younger accident victim may have greater earnings damages than an older one.  If you return to work after an accident, it is important that your employer document this information in your personnel file.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you are injured because of someone else's negligence, and you are unable to return to work, you have a duty to mitigate the amount of lost earnings you recover. This means you have a duty to take other reasonable steps to reduce your damages. For example, you have a duty to accept a reasonable job within your limitations, even if it pays less than your former job. If you do not, you might not be allowed to recover the difference between the earnings from the new job and those that you earned from your previous job.    Jurisdictional differences may apply.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Duty to Mitigate Damages for Future Lost Earnings?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"It is essential that an injured person try to \"mitigate\" damages for lost earnings. This means they must make an effort to not lose more than necessary. For example, if an injured person is taking medicine that makes him drowsy and unable to drive, that person must get help with transportation. Otherwise, the person will not be able to get to work, and the employer could legitimately fire (discharge) the person for not showing up. By failing to get help with transportation, the injured person is not \"mitigating damages\". The employer could argue that the person lost his job because he was irresponsible, not because he was injured.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If the conduct that caused a claimant's harm continues, a court will expect the claimant to take reasonable steps to prevent future harm instead of demanding the full amount from the defendant. The law believes it would be unfair to hold the defendant responsible for harm that the claimant could have reasonably avoided. The need to avoid or reduce damages is known as the duty to mitigate damages. In a case involving lost earnings, the duty to mitigate damages may require a claimant to look for new work or to undertake training that allows him or her to get back to work.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The injured person has a duty to keep damages as low as possible after the injury. For example, if an injured person returns to work at a slower pace, he can file a claim for lost earnings for the time he is working more slowly. However, if he chooses a career with less stress simply because it is easier than his past job, then he cannot recover for lost earnings relating to the new career (as opposed to the old one).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you suffer a personal injury that interferes with your earning potential, you can sue the person who caused your injury for your future lost earnings. However, when figuring out damages, the court will consider your duty to mitigate. In other words, you have an obligation to make reasonable efforts to limit your future economic losses. This may include going back to school, seeking alternative employment, accepting a demotion, or making modifications or adaptations to continue working.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If your injury limits your ability to earn an income, your lost earnings could be a substantial part of your damages. When calculating these damages, the defendant will have the duty to mitigate them. That is, he must help to reduce or limit the damages to your future lost earnings. This is generally accomplished by hiring doctors, rehabilitation specialists, trainers and other professionals who can teach you how to learn or re-learn income-producing skills. The defendant must also help pay them.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of No Deduction for Workersâ€™ Compensation Benefits Paid?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you get workers' compensation for a job injury, the Social Security Administration (SSA) has to coordinate your workers' compensation benefits with your Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) benefits to avoid overpayments. To do this, SSA finds the total of your workers' compensation benefits and your SSDI benefits, then compares that total to a guaranteed minimum. The guaranteed minimum is $100 as of January 2009. The total of your workers' compensation and SSDI benefits must not be less than the guaranteed minimum. If the total is less than the guaranteed minimum, the difference in the amount of benefits is deducted from your workers' compensation benefits before the Social Security benefits are paid.     Because of this coordination, if you get workers' compensation and you have a work-related disability, you may be unsure whether you qualify for Social Security disability benefits. You are, however, entitled to apply for benefits.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you receive a Social Security disability benefit and a workers' compensation award, the SSA will calculate your benefit as follows:     First, your Social Security disability benefit is reduced by 20 percent;     Then, the amount of workers' compensation you receive is compared to the reduced amount of your Social Security disability benefit, and the larger of the two is selected.       This ensures that you receive at least a 20% increase in your benefits because you are being awarded workers' compensation in addition to your Social Security disability benefits.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you get Social Security disability benefits and workers' compensation benefits at the same time, we may have to reduce your benefit amount, depending on the total amount of your workers' compensation benefits, the total amount of your Social Security disability benefits, and when your workers' compensation benefits started.    The first $1,260 a month of your workers' compensation benefits will not be deducted from your other benefits, and neither will the first $1,260 a month of your benefits. This is true whether your benefits are for you, your widow(er) or your child. For example, if you are receiving Social Security retirement benefits and you lose your job due to a workplace injury, you may remain eligible for the workers' compensation benefits. However, since you are receiving benefits from two different government agencies, a reduction of your total monthly benefits may apply.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you get Social Security disability benefits and workers' compensation benefits at the same time, the two benefits together can't be more than 80 percent of your average current earnings before you became disabled. In order to keep the two benefits from going over that 80 percent limit, we need to reduce your Social Security benefits by any workers' compensation you get. This is called a \"workers' compensation offset.\"    When we offset your Social Security benefits, we do it on a dollar-for-dollar basis. This means the net effect is that you'll just be transferring some of your disability income from Social Security to workers' compensation.    For more information, read How Work Can Affect Your Benefits.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you receive workers' compensation benefits and Social Security benefits at the same time, the Social Security Administration may have to reduce your Social Security benefits. This is called an \"offset\". It is not a \"deduction\". Your benefits will not be reduced by the amount you receive in workers' compensation.    The most common type of offset occurs when you receive Social Security retirement or disability benefits. If you are eligible for an offset, your benefits will be subject to the offset during the first year you receive them. If you continue receiving benefits, the offset will not apply starting in the second year that you receive the benefits. However, if your entitlement to workers' compensation ends in this second and subsequent years, your benefits will be subject to the offset during the month your entitlement to workers' compensation ends and the following month.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Disorder - describes an unusual, unexpected, or worrying pattern of psychological features that cause significant personal distress or interfere with a person's ability to perform physical, mental, and social functions. We are all born with, or develop, certain vulnerabilities to disorders.     Dangerousness - we expect people to be able to control their behavior. However, in some disorders people's behavior appears out of control. They may be dangerous to themselves or others. The problem is serious if this is a person's only way of coping. Here, we will look at different types of addictions and eating disorders.     Emotional Pain - people with disorders can be very unhappy. They may not be able to enjoy life. They may even want to die.     Personal Distress - the way some people feel and behave keeps them from doing normal activities like working, going to school, and spending time with family and friends.     Impairment - when a person's disorder interferes with day-to-day activities like taking care of yourself, sleeping, eating and communicating, it is called impairment.     Social Norms - every culture has social norms. These are society's rules for how we should behave. People who act differently than society expects can be labeled \"disordered.\" But certain groups, as a whole, may appear unusual to others. Society's social norms include prejudice and discrimination. This means what we think is unusual can change. It also means that different groups can tolerate different levels of diversity.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When we speak of mental illness, we are in fact describing a wide variety of disorders. Research has shown that in many cases, genes passed down by parents play a role in mental illness. But it is not so simple as \"genes cause mental illness\". Other factors also play a role such as stress or a history of abuse. Studying mental illnesses is difficult because mental health and illness exist on a continuum; there are no clear dividing lines between the states of mental health and mental illness as we cannot measure a healthy or ill state of mind as we can other parts of the body. In such cases, physicians look for clusters of signs and symptoms which tend to occur together and are usually seen in association with each other in the population. Because of the variety of mental illnesses, most mental illnesses are diagnosed by a health care professional, such as a psychiatrist or a psychologist, based upon how the patient describes their thoughts and feelings, or how the patient appears or acts. There are also diseases other than primary psychiatric disorders that can cause mental symptoms. Sometimes illnesses involving other parts of the body can affect a person's thinking, emotions, and behavior. Please note that these cases may not be the most recent and as a result they may not be good law in your jurisdiction. Redlinger v. County of Los Angeles, 768 F.2d 357 - Court of Appeals, 9th Circuit 1985 The case involves the question of whether county employees'' actions in accepting a grant of immunity from the state and thereby ''waiving the liability limition contained in California Government Code section 815.6,\" gives rise to federal law claims. Plaintiffs filed suit against the City of Los Angeles; the Mayor of Los Angeles; the City Council for Los Angeles; the City Attorney of Los Angeles; the Los Angeles Police Department; the Department of Mental Health of Los Angeles County; Dr. Daniel Smith; Dr. Martin Fliegel; Dr. William Friedman; Dean Cambias; and Joan Kraft. They allege violations of: the Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments; the Americans with Disabilities Act; the Rehabilitation Act; Title VII of the Civil Rights Act; sections 1983, 1985(3) and 1986 of the United States Code; and the California Constitution. Plaintiffs seek reimbursement for medical expenses; punitive damages; nominal damages; injunctive relief; declaratory relief; attorney's fees; and costs. Court of Appeals, 9th Circuit affirms summary judgment and reverses preliminary injunction against City's commitment procedures. In the Matter of the Commitment of Taylor, 24 P.3d 587, 582 CO 95 - Supreme Court of Colorado 2001 Pursuant to COLO.REV.STAT. (C.R.S.) 27-65-102, a person is gravely disabled when by reason of a mental illness the person is in danger of serious harm due to a failure to provide for his or her essential needs of health or safety. At issue is whether, in order to be \"gravely disabled,\" is the person required to be unable to provide for his or her essential needs under any and all circumstances, or whether being unable to provide for one's needs in usual circumstances under normal influences may suffice to establish grave disability. Court of Appeals of Indiana - Division I 2005 The State of Indiana is also a petitioner here. Judicial review whether state law violates federal law. In the Matter of the Commitment of Joseph, 143 P.3d 578 - Supreme Court of the State of Washington 2006 Under chapter 71.05 RCW, a person with a mental disorder can be involuntarily committed if that person is dangerous to other persons or gravely disabled. completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Obligation to Prove-Reasonable Doubt Madd, Encyclopedia of Crime and Justice, p. 1104-1106 When the government prosecutes someone for an offense, the prosecutor must prove each element of the criminal offense beyond a reasonable doubt. At first glance, this rule might seem to guarantee that an innocent person will not be punished. After all, if there is reasonable doubt, the defendant must be found not guilty. In practice, however, innocent persons have been and are punished. The standard is a high one, but it does not require absolute certainty.    What exactly does the phrase beyond a reasonable doubt mean? The phrase is to be understood in its \"common and approved usage\" or as the people of a jurisdiction understand it. Inmodel jury instructions for a criminal case, the United States Department of Justice states that       Reasonable doubt is doubt based upon reason and common sense. It is not mere possible doubt, but is such a doubt as would make a reasonable person hesitate to act. If, after careful and impartial consideration of all the evidence, you are firmly convinced that the defendant is guilty, the doubt has been removed from your mind. On the other hand, if you think there is a reason to believe he may not be guilty, you have a reasonable doubt.    Objections have been raised to the phrase beyond a reasonable doubt. Some critics have noted that courts largely have refused to define reasonable doubt, that jurors do not necessarily understand the term in the same way, and that when the concept of reasonable doubt is defined, the definitions differ and vary in quality. Other critics have argued that the functions of the reasonable doubt standard have been taken over by the presumption of innocence, that the difference between preponderance of the evidence and reasonable doubt has become unclear, and that because scientific evidence is evaluated statistically, there can be no reasonable doubt about guilt. Some have suggested that jury deliberations be studied or that people withlowa ctivation in the amygdalae (brains areas responsible for processing social and emotional reactions) be excluded from jury service in heavily emotional cases. One proposal to address the vagueness of the standard would be to provide jury instructions that proscribe quantitative standards such as a 90% degree of certainty that a defendant is guilty.    On the other hand, it has been argued that the presumption of innocence and the obligation to prove a fact beyond a reasonable doubt are intertwined and must be viewed \"in conjunction with each other.\" It has been further argued that the standard merely guides the jury's conscience and that the test for wrongful conviction must be \"whether the judgment was consistent with the 'conscious will' of the finder of fact.\" It is reasonable to doubt dating violence prevention, persons, United States department of justice, U.S. department of justice, legal information institute, Cornell law school","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The prima facie case consisting of an inference of guilt from direct evidence, or from indirect or circumstantial evidence, must be sufficient as well as rational. prompt: What is the principle of fiduciary Duty Explained?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Principle of Fiduciary Duties\n\t\t\t\t\tA fiduciary relationship is one in which one party lives and acts at the expense of another. In such relationships trusts develop, thus the use of the term fiduciary, which derives from the latin fidere, meaning 'to trust'. One party has a special trust and confidence in another, such as a corporation or government placing certain powers in the hands of its officers or agents. A fiduciary duty is the obligation to act in the best interest of another. For example, a company's director (the fiduciary) is expected to perform all duties in the best interest of the company.     \t\t\t\t\t\t\t    \t\t\t\t\t\t\t     Source: www.investopedia.com","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What is a fiduciary duty? A fiduciary duty is the highest standard of care. The person who has the fiduciary duty is called a \"fiduciary.\" A fiduciary is expected to be extremely loyal to the person to whom he owes the duty (the \"principal\"): he must not put his personal interest before the duty, and he must not profit from his position as a fiduciary, unless the principal consents.    An agent has a fiduciary duty to his principal. This includes duties of loyalty and good faith. Also, as a fiduciary, the agent must avoid conflicts of interest. The agent is not permitted to take advantage of the principal unless the principal consents or is deemed to have consented. For example, if a principal hires a real estate agent, the real estate agent is a fiduciary and must put the principal's interest before his own.    A director and officer of a corporation owes his corporation fiduciary duties including duties of good faith, loyalty and care.    United States Department of Labor","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A fiduciary duty is the highest standard of care at either law or equity. A person who has to abide by fiduciary duties is called a fiduciary. These duties are created either through a formal, legal relationship or a personal relationship, and they require the fiduciary to act in good faith and with a view to the interests of the other person. Fiduciaries are usually expected to be conscientious, loyal, and not to put their interests before the interest of the other person. The duties of a trustee of a trust are an example of fiduciary duties at law; the duties of a corporate officer or director are an example of fiduciary duties at equity.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When working in a fiduciary capacity, you are legally and ethically obliged to put another party's interests ahead of your own. Fiduciaries must provide full and fair disclosure of any potential conflicts of interest.    Let's say you are in charge of investing money for another person. The person who you are working for is called the principal. To be a fiduciary, you have to put the principal's interests first. You cannot make investments for your own benefit. If you were to do this, you would have a conflict of interest.    The federal government oversees fiduciaries for Social Security Disability benefits, employee benefit plans, banks, savings and loans, and credit unions. Some states regulate fiduciaries for local government and other retirement benefits. You can work as a fiduciary for a living. You can also volunteer your services to a relative or friend (though being a fiduciary is a big responsibility).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Corporate officers and directors have many duties. One of these duties is the duty of loyalty, which includes the duty to avoid conflicts of interest. Fiduciary duty is a legal duty to act solely in another party's interests. The fiduciary is held to a high standard of honesty and full disclosure and must not obtain any personal benefit at the expense of the other party. For example, trustees of a trust have a fiduciary duty to the trust beneficiaries to prudently manage and invest trust assets.    The duty of loyalty requires directors and officers to put the corporation's interests ahead of their own. It requires them to avoid conflicts of interest when possible, or to fully disclose any conflicts. Conflicts of interest may arise in the case of self-dealing or when directors or officers usurp a corporate opportunity for themselves. Self-dealing occurs if they engage in any transaction with the corporation, directly or on behalf of another party that benefits personally from the transaction. To usurp a corporate opportunity is to take for one's self a business opportunity that a corporation might be interested in.    They are protected if:       - The transaction was fair to the corporation, or    - The material facts of the transaction and their interest in it were disclosed or known to the board, and the board approved, or    - The material facts of the transaction and their interest in it were disclosed or known by the shareholders, and the shareholders approved.       With certain exceptions, officers and directors are not liable for monetary damages to the corporation for breach of duty, if they meet the above standards. Under some circumstances, they may be personally liable for penalties under federal securities laws enforcement actions.     (From: NOLO.com)","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What does Duty of Undivided Loyaltyâ€”Essential Factual Elements require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A broker who acts as an agent for (represents) either the buyer or seller has a duty of undivided loyalty to the party he or she represents. This means that the broker or agent cannot represent the interests of the other party in the same transaction. For example, a broker can represent the interests of the seller through a listing agreement or the interests of the buyer through a buyer agency or buyer brokerage agreement, but may not do both in the same transaction. The duty of undivided loyalty also prohibits an agent from ever acting in his or her own interest or in the interest of another party or person in a way that is adverse to the interest of his or her client. prompt: How is Duties of Stockbrokerâ€”Speculative Securities explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The elements of stockbroker duties related to speculative securities are listed below. To decide whether the defendant stockbroker violated a duty, you must decide whether the plaintiff has proved each element of one of the duties by a preponderance of the evidence:       Speculative securities may be inappropriate for the plaintiff if the plaintiff lacks       - Sufficient education or experience to understand the risks of the speculative securities; or    - Financial resources or income adequate to absorb the loss of the investment; or    - A larger number of different investments to reduce risks of loss from any one investment.       If the speculative securities were inappropriate for the plaintiff, the defendant stockbroker may have breached a duty to the plaintiff unless the stockbroker undertook reasonable efforts to determine that the speculative securities were appropriate for the plaintiff. Once the stockbroker undertakes those efforts, the stockbroker has no further duty with respect to determining appropriateness.        If the plaintiff has created a bank deposit account or other safe investment to provide financial security in the event of loss or the plaintiff was informed by the defendant stockbroker, in writing, that the investment is speculative, then the speculative securities may not be inappropriate for the plaintiff even if the plaintiff lacks:       - Sufficient education or experience to understand the risks of the speculative securities; or    - Financial resources or income adequate to absorb the loss of the investment; or    - A larger number of different investments to reduce risks of loss from any one investment.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Section 247.01 of the Florida Jury Instructions in Civil Cases provides the following instruction to the jury about Duties of Stockbrokerâ€”Speculative Securities: The stockbroker who sold the Plaintiff worthless stock was a fiduciary. A fiduciary is a person who is entrusted with property. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A stockbroker is a person or firm in the business of buying and selling shares of stock in companies on behalf of customers. Many stocks are sold through tall, glass-walled buildings filled with workers shouting at each other and waving papers, called stock exchanges. The most famous is the New York Stock Exchange (the Dow Jones ticker tape gives the price of stocks that are trading in New York). Many stocks are sold through an electronic network. Stockbrokers buy and sell stocks for customers on both types of exchanges.    There is a wide range of stockbrokers, and they are competitive with each other. They are different prices and services and cater to different types of customers.    You, too, can buy shares of stock. But before you do, you will want to compare prices and services of different stockbrokers. You may want to get letters from people you trust who use the stockbroker's services. Stockbrokers are required to be registered with the appropriate regulatory agency - and Licensed. You should check with that agency to make sure the license is still good.    Speculative securities, also called \"penny stocks,\" are cheap, highly risky stocks. There is a limited chance of making money and a good chance of losing all or most of what you invest. Speculative stocks are often sold by companies with little or no income or assets and by new companies that have not been tested by the business cycle. Speculative stocks are often stocks that have been \"delisted\" from the New York, American, or Over-the-Counter (OTC) exchanges and have moved to the \"pink sheets.\"    Beware of cold calls about speculative stocks. You should be especially careful about buying stocks over the telephone or being pressured into buying speculative stocks quickly. Check with a lawyer or a financial advisor before spending money on them, and be prepared to lose what you pay.    For more information, see the Federal Trade Commission Consumer Alert: Duties of Stockbroker: Speculative Securities.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When you invest in stocks and other securities, you expect the company whose stocks you buy to make money. Otherwise, what's the point? But, some companies whose stocks are sold on the over-the-counter markets have little or no business at all or have major financial problems. Speculative companies often do not have to meet the strict listing requirements of other stock markets. When their stocks are not listed on an exchange they are usually traded over-the-counter. Some of these companies have only a business plan and hope to raise money by trading their stock. Because these companies may not have any revenues, investors are taking a \"stab in the dark.\"    If you buy speculative stocks that have little or no business, you run the risk of losing your entire investment.    Speculative stocks are different from penny stocks. Penny stocks generally trade at a low price and are not on a major market or exchange. Some penny stocks are speculative, but not all.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Investment Company Institute v. Camp, 401 F.3d 717 (dc cir. 2005) is a case relating to Duties of Stockbrokerâ€”Speculative Securities. Plaintiffs are mutual fund industry groups. Defendants are officials of the treasury and securities oversight agencies. The plaintiffs challenged a joint rule prescribing duties of stockbrokers and others when making recommendations involving \"speculative securities.\" The rule applies to non-exchange-listed stocks, certain over-the-counter derivatives, options on futures, etc. The rule imposes duties of care and loyalty; requires a determination of investor suitability; imposes disclosure requirements; and seeks to modify existing doctrines. The plaintiffs argue that aspects of the rule violate requirements of 15 USC 80a-35 and the Administrative Procedure Act. The Rule applies in full force to recommendations made on or after August 31, 2005. The court affirms the agencies' authority to prescribe a rule imposing duties of care and loyalty. However, the district court properly held that the agencies must coordinate their efforts to ensure consistency in provisions concerning conflicts of interest. The district court properly ordered rescission of a certain provision of the rule on reconsideration. The court remands for reconciliation of the contradictory determinations concerning the rule's effect on market stability. The district court correctly concluded that the agencies failed to justify a 200% markup safe harbor. The court remands to conclude whether to impose a different safe harbor. The court agrees that a finding of economic impact triggers the requirements of the Regulatory Flexibility Act. The court remands the issues of final agency action, mootness, and the rule as a prohibited \"rule of trade practice.\" Affirmed in part, reversed in part; case remanded.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How is Duty of Disclosure by Real Estate Broker to Client explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The jury instructions on this page explain to the jury the law on duty of disclosure by a real estate broker to a client. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The real estate broker is required by law to serve you as a client with \"undivided loyalty.\" You may be their sole client. A sales agent (sometimes called a salesperson) who is affiliated with a broker represents the broker's client. The broker's agent may be the sole client or one of the clients. If you are a client of the broker or the broker's agent, it is very important that the broker and agent act loyally in your interests. In that situation, the broker and the agent cannot represent another party to your transaction unless all parties agree in writing.    The real estate brokers and agents are required by law to advise you whether they do or do not represent you as a client. In most situations (but not all), they must do this in writing before you provide confidential information. Confidential information is information which, if disclosed, may harm the other party's negotiating position.    When representing you as client, the real estate licensees acting for you are responsible to you for a wide range of duties. Those duties include a duty of disclosure. The duty of disclosure requires the licensees to tell you of any information concerning the transaction which may be material to your decision to buy, sell, or lease the property.    However, law prohibits real estate brokers and salespersons from giving legal advice.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"\"Duty of Disclosure by Real Estate Broker to Client\" is explained to the jury as follows: A real estate broker has a duty to his or her client to disclose material facts affecting the value of the property. You must decide whether the defendant was informed of the alleged defect and the extent to which the defendant had reason to believe that such defect existed and that it materially affected the value of the property. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Duty of Disclosure by Real Estate Broker to Client is explained to the jury. Every licensed real estate broker in the State of Indiana is required to provide the following to a prospective real estate customer: (1) the name of the broker and/or the brokerage company; (2) if a licensed salesperson is the broker's agent, the name of the salesperson; (3) a written explanation of the agency relationships which are permitted under Indiana law; and (4) a written statement of the broker's duties. This Court's written statement of the broker's duties includes the unsafe buildings which the owners do not know about. When a real estate broker agrees to represent as a client either the buyer or the seller of real estate, the real estate broker becomes the agent of that client and is then bound by both common law and statute to perform certain duties. Some of these duties include the following: to act solely in the interests of the client in all matters within the scope of the agency; to seek a sale or purchase at the price and upon the terms authorized by the client; to disclose to the client all information that the agent knows or should know and that might reasonably affect the client's ability to receive fair and full compensation; to maintain the confidentiality of any information given to the agent by the client for a reasonable time after termination of the agency, except as to matters to which the client has consented or as to which disclosure is required by law; to timely account to the client for all money and property received; to obey all lawful instructions and to act reasonably and with due care. Most specifically with respect to disclosure, the real estate broker shall disclose to the client adverse material facts involving the property.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How is Breach of Duty by Real Estate Sellerâ€™s Agentâ€”Inaccurate Information in Multiple Listing Serviceâ€”Essential Factual Elements (Civ. Code, Â§ 1088) explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Judicial Council has prepared the following instruction for use in a trial. It explains to the jury the essential facts of breach of duty by a real estate seller's agent for inaccurate information in the Multiple Listing Service, as set out in Civil Code section 1088. You may use this instruction as it now reads or as a guide to write your own.     Breach of Duty by Real Estate Seller's Agent - Inaccurate Information in Multiple Listing Service - Essential Factual Elements (Civ. Code, Â§ 1088)    To succeed on a claim that a real estate seller's agent has breached a duty that arises from inaccurate information given by seller in a listing entered into a Multiple Listing Service, plaintiff must prove each of the following:        1. that the agent is a listing agent;    2. that the stated or checked information about the property was inaccurate information; and     3. that the inaccurate information in the listing was the proximate cause of damage to the buyer.       The word \"proximate\" means that the inaccurate information was a substantial cause of the damage sustained.     If you find that plaintiff has failed to prove any one of these elements, your verdict should be for defendant. prompt: What is the principle of Constructive Fraud (Civ. Code, Â§ 1573)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud is a breach of duty which, regardless of the moral guilt of the person who commits it, the law declares fraudulent because of its tendency to deceive others, to violate confidence, or to injure public interests. The most common of these duties is a duty of utmost good faith and fair dealing. A constructive fraud may consist of an act, or an omission to act. Under the Civil Code, constructive fraud happens when any of the following duties or obligations are breached:       - Duty to deal fairly with another;    - Duty not to take unconscientious advantage of another;    - Duty to disclose all facts which one is obliged to disclose;    - Duty to abstain from taking any unconscientious advantage of another person by means of a misleading statement; or    - A trust or fiduciary relation between the person who commits constructive fraud and the person damaged by it.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud occurs when an act, although apparently fair, unconsciously works in injury to a party whose interests are entrusted to the actor. Constructive fraud consists of a breach of duty which, irrespective of moral guilt, the law declares fraudulent because of its tendency to deceive others, to violate confidence, or to cause injury. Constructive fraud is presumed from the relations of the parties; actual fraud must be proved. (Civ. Code, Â§ 1573.)","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud is a breach of duty that is \"without doing any actual or positive fraud\" and that \"the law declares to be a fraud, because of its tendency to deceive others, to violate a confidence, or to produce injury, or because of the circumvention or oppression of others.\" (Civ. Code, Â§ 1573; Sain v. Hall, 10 Cal.App.4th 359, 363 (1992).) It does not arise from a person's design to commit it or any actual intent to deceive others, and results from ignorance, heedlessness, or carelessness on someone's part.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Every contract implies not only what is expressly stated in it, but also all the necessary conditions to make it a lawful contract.  Constructive fraud is a breach of duty which is without the acquiring party's fault and which gains that party an advantage to the prejudice of the other. This is often the case where the parties are in a confidential or fiduciary relationship. Like actual fraud (deceit) it vitiates consent and the party whose consent was obtained by fraud is entitled to rescind the agreement (revoke it and restore the parties to their position before the contract was made).  If you have a dispute involving actual or constructive fraud, an experienced attorney should be consulted.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud is a breach of legal or equitable duty which, irrespective of moral guilt, the law declares fraudulent because of its tendency to deceive others, to violate confidence, or to influence official behavior or because of the confidence reposed in the person in fault. Constructive fraud is not based on intent to deceive or defraud. It is also called \"involuntary fraud.\"","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What case law supports Constructive Fraud (Civ. Code, Â§ 1573)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Constructive fraud is the term used in California for acts that may lead to fraud but do not involve a fraudulent intent. See Evid. Code Â§ 412; Civil Code Â§ 1573. It differs from actual fraud in that, with constructive fraud, the person being sued made a mistake, unconscious ignorance, grossly negligent, or has a duty not to profit from their wrong, even if there was no intent to deceive, manipulate, or cheat. Courts have recognized that a claim of constructive fraud requires the same elements as a claim of actual fraud except that constructive fraud lacks a fraudulent intent (Mensing v. People's Choice Financial Corp. (1996) 49 Cal.App.4th 1524, 1532.) Constructive fraud can be based on a fiduciary or confidential relationship (Boeken v. Philip Morris, Inc. (2005) 127 Cal.App.4th 1640, 1652); a failure to disclose relevant facts (see Archer v. United Pacific Ins. Co. (1966) 244 Cal.App.2d 331, 344); misrepresentations (Abrams v. Whether the transferor transferred the essential assets of the business to a lienor who held the assets as security for an antecedent debt, or to a creditor or an insider;     5. Whether the value of the consideration received by the transferor was reasonably equivalent to the value of the asset transferred;     8. Whether the transferor was threatened with litigation or other action by a creditor;     9. Whether the transfer was of a portion of the transferor's ownership interest in a closely held business or a beneficial interest in a trust; and    10. This is called the \"transfer of guilt.\" Five of the nine people were actually guilty. The issue is which people should be blamed. In transfer of guilt, the issue is not whether the crime was committed, but rather who committed the crime.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}
