prompt: What is the legal standard for the Insolvency Explained?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The legal standard for Louisiana's insolvency law is based on the \"balance sheet\" test, not the \"cash flow\" test. In other words, the law requires the Commissioner to find that the insurer's total liabilities exceed its total assets. This is the exact opposite of the usual requirement to be considered solvent. In general, when determining whether an insurer is solvent, the law requires the use of a \"cash flow\" test. This means that the insurer has to be able to make its payments as they come due. This is the same as a requirement in the law prohibiting insolvent insurers from doing business. But under the insolvency law, where there is a finding of insolvency, the law requires that the insurer not be able to fund its losses. The purpose for this is to protect the public. The law would want to prevent an insurer that it knows does not have enough money to make payments from continuing to sell insurance.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Insolvency Act 1986 sets out how insolvency procedures should be administered in Great Britain. It establishes legally binding insolvency procedures and regulates the activities of insolvency practitioners. Insolvency legislation is designed to strike a balance between the interests of creditors and those of debtors who have become insolvent through misfortune rather than mismanagement. Terms Straight bankruptcy: an order that you have to pay creditors what you can and that any assets above a certain value are realised (for example sold) in order to raise money to pay creditors Bankruptcy restrictions order: a court order that increases the length of time your bankruptcy restrictions apply Bankruptcy restrictions undertakings: an undertaking to the court by the person who is bankrupt that increases the length of time their bankruptcy restrictions apply Debt Relief Order (DRO): an official notice that says if you follow it's restrictions for 12 months, any debts covered by it will be written off Insolvency practitioner: an individual or business authorised or licensed to act in relation to an insolvency appointment Official receiver: a government official who investigates the affairs of a person or company in bankruptcy Personal insolvency arrangements: make an offer to creditors to repay some or all of your debts over a reasonable period of time. Each creditor can accept or reject the proposal. The process can end in bankruptcy if it is rejected or if the terms of the arrangement cannot be met. Sequestration order: an order that you have to pay creditors what you can and that any assets above a certain value are realised (for example sold) in order to raise money to pay creditors, applicable in Scotland only Voluntary arrangements: a formal agreement with your creditors which is designed to help you pay off your debts over a period of time. The agreement is used for liquidation of debts and continues on until successful complete payment of debts and expenses.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are the elements of the Presumption of Insolvency?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The presumption of insolvency is established by C.R.S. 38-49-101(2). See 1 COLLIER ON BANKRUPTCY ¶ 4.01[2][d] (Alan N. Resnick & Henry J. Sommer eds., 16th ed. 2014). That statute provides that a debtor is presumed to be insolvent if he is unable to pay debts as they mature or one of the following four elements are met: (1) the aggregate nonexempt assets of the debtor are less than the amount that would reasonably be required to pay all unsecured claims; (2) the sum of the debtor's debts is greater than all of the debtor's property, at a fair valuation; (3) the debtor has executed a conveyance or transfer of property or has incurred obligations, with intent to hinder, delay or defraud any creditor of the debtor; or (4) the debtor has committed an act of bankruptcy as defined in Colorado law.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The presumption of insolvency appears in Section 8 of the Bankruptcy Code. It operates as if the debtor has filed a verification of insolvency; in such situations, the debtor is not required to verify insolvency in any other way. The presumption has two parts - either part satisfies the presumption. They are as follows:       - In the case where a debtor has not filed a petition under Title 11 of the United States Code (\"Bankruptcy Code\") in the immediately preceding 180 days, the presumption of insolvency arises if the claims of general unsecured creditors in an amount not less than $15,000 exceeds the value of the debtor's interest in property, at a fair valuation, exclusive of property necessary to be retained for the debtor's personal use and consumption.    - In the case where a debtor has filed a petition under Title 11 of the United States Code (\"Bankruptcy Code\") in the immediately preceding 180 days, the presumption of insolvency arises if either of the following conditions are met:              - the debtor has made a settlement under Section 1056.06, 1056.07 or 1056.11 and failed to receive a discharge under Section 1056.08; or        - the debtor executed a settlement agreement under Section 1056.06, 1056.07 or 1056.11 but has not delivered the executed agreement to the court or has yet to make the payments required under the agreement.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The presumption of insolvency under the Bankruptcy Act is based on the assumption that if a person does not pay a debt that is due and demandable, such person is already insolvent. There are four elements under the presumption of insolvency under the Bankruptcy Act:","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The presumption of insolvency includes all of the following:       - The aggregate indebtedness of a person or business is greater than the fair market value of the property owned by the debtor (balance sheet insolvency).    - The aggregate indebtedness of a person or business is greater than the amount that the person or business can pay as it becomes due (cash flow insolvency).    - Misapplication of funds belonging to a debtor, a secured party, or a trustee; or the making of a preferential transfer or a fraudulent conveyance.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"CIVIL CODE SECTION 3439.08 - 3439.08. Affirmative defense: good faith purchaser for value; transfer in good faith; expiration of six-month period; burden of proof; good faith enforcement of lien on security for transfer of an interest in a mobile home; multiple transferees; limitation        (a) A transfer of personal property or an interest in real property, including a transfer to a self-settled trust, is not voidable under this chapter to a transferee that proves all of the following:              (1) That the transferee gave reasonably equivalent value in exchange for the transfer or that the transferee took for a present value an obligation, due or to become due, in the amount of the agreed upon value.               (2) That the transferee took the transfer without knowledge that the transfer was in violation of this chapter.               (3) That the transferee took the transfer in good faith.              (f) (1) For purposes of subdivision (a), an interest in property that is received by a transferee more than six months after the date on which a transfer is made is deemed to have been received without actual or constructive knowledge of the transfer.     (b) A transfer of an interest in an organization to a transferee that qualifies as a good faith purchaser for value under subdivision (a) is also a transfer that is made in good faith.    (c) For purposes of subdivision (a), a value is reasonably equivalent to the value of the transferred asset if the value of the asset at the time of transfer does not differ from the value given for it by more than ten percent.    (d) A transfer that is voidable pursuant to this chapter is voidable by one or more creditors but not by other creditors holding or acquiring their claims after one or more creditors has begun a proceeding to recover a judgment against the transferor or attach the property transferred.     (e) A creditor, as defined in Section 1782 of the Code of Civil Procedure, has the burden of proof with respect to each element of an affirmative defense.    (g) (1) Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of subdivision (a), a transfer made in good faith shall not be voidable under Section 3439.04 or 3439.05 if both of the following apply:              (A) The transfer is a transfer of an interest in a mobile home to an organization that is a creditor selling the interest for the purpose of enforcing a lien on the mobile home.               (B) The amount of the sale is the amount secured by the lien plus the amount of all accrued and unpaid real property taxes and assessments and lien charges, including interest on those amounts, for which the seller is liable.              (2) The exemption provided by paragraph (1) applies to all sales by one or more sellers to one or more purchasers.               (Stats. 2024, Ch. 54, Sec. 10. Effective date: 5/16/2024.)","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What case law supports  affirmative defense - statute of limitations - actual and constructive fraud (Civ. Code, Â§ 3439.09(a), (b))? The statute of limitations for actual fraud is three years, and the statute of limitations for constructive fraud is two years. The three-year statutory period for actual fraud begins to run from the date plaintiff discovered, or might through reasonable diligence have discovered, the fraud. The discovery rule allows for tolling of the statutory period. Section 338(c) of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that an action for relief on the grounds of fraud must be commenced within three years \"after the discovery, by the aggrieved party, of the facts constituting the fraud\". The statute of limitations for actual fraud does not begin to run until the fraud is, or should have been, discovered. The discovery rule applies to both actual and constructive fraud. The Attorney General's staff determined that a cause of action for constructive fraud against a public entity's employees or agents accrues upon the occurrence of such fraud, unless delayed accrual results from the application of the discovery rule or the doctrine of equitable tolling. The two-year statutory period for constructive fraud begins to run from the time plaintiff sustains the actual damage, not from the time the deceptive practice occurred. Under California's Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA), section 3439.09 of the Civil Code sets forth the statute of limitations with respect to actions for actual and constructive fraud. Section 3439.09(a) provides that an action for actual fraud \"may be brought within 4 years after the transfer was made or the obligation was incurred or, if later, within 1 year after the transfer or obligation was or could reasonably have been discovered by the claimant.\" Section 3439.09(b) provides that an action for constructive fraud \"may be brought within 4 years after the transfer was made or the obligation was incurred.\" (Code Civ. Proc., Â§Â§ 335, 339.)","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What does Termination for Failure to Pay Rentâ€”Essential Factual Elements require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"To evict someone for not paying rent, a landlord must first give proper notice. If the tenant does not move by the deadline in the notice, the landlord may file an unlawful detainer action (UDA) in court to evict the tenant. The tenant may defend against the UDA. In such a case, the landlord must prove at trial that (1) the tenant owes rent; (2) the landlord made a demand for payment; and (3) the tenant refused to pay or did not pay the full amount.     After a trial, if the landlord prevails, the court will issue a judgment for possession. The landlord may then request a writ of possession from the court. It introduces a court officer to the dispute who will supervise the eviction. Once a court officer supervises the eviction, the tenant may be physically removed. We strongly recommend that landlords avoid physically removing tenants themselves because physical removal could lead to liability for damages.     Michigan Legal Help has a summary of the procedure that must be followed for an eviction.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What does Termination of Month-to-Month Tenancyâ€”Essential Factual Elements require under the law?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"New York requires landlords to give tenants reasonable advance written notice of the termination of their month-to-month tenancy. For tenants who have to move out, this gives them the opportunity to find new housing. The length of the notice depends on how long the tenant has lived in the apartment:       - For a tenancy that has lasted less than six months, 30 days' advance written notice   - For a tenancy that has lasted between six months and two years, 60 days' advance written notice   - For a tenancy that has lasted more than two years 90 days' advance written notice","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The termination notice for a month-to-month tenancy is a document that informs the tenant that the landlord has terminated the tenancy. Viewing this document is a good first step in preparing to contest an unlawful detainer complaint on the ground that proper notice was not given. Like all notices, the termination notice must contain certain information. The termination notice must:        - Inform the tenant the tenancy has been terminated and that the tenant must quit the premises;    - Give the tenant the proper period of notice to quit (depending on whether the landlord or tenant is in breach of the agreement, this is usually three days, 30 days, or 60 days);     - Be signed by the person giving the notice; and     - Be properly served on the tenant.       Depending on the circumstances, the termination notice may be a 30 or 60 day termination notice or a 3-day notice. A 3-day termination notice can be a 3-day notice to pay rent or quit, a 3-day notice to perform covenants or quit, or a 3-day notice to quit for nuisance or waste, criminal activity, etc.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under the law, if either the landlord or the tenant wants to end a month-to-month tenancy, they must notify each other, at least one full month in advance. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Instruction No. 22.260       Sufficiency and Service of Notice of Termination for Nuisance or Unlawful Use       A property owner may request termination for a nuisance or unlawful use of real property by filing a notice of termination with the city, county, or city and county having jurisdiction to enforce the law prohibiting the use. The notice shall inform the owner that under the Act the owner may avoid termination of the use by doing one of the following within 40 days after service of the notice:              - Correct the violation causing termination, if possible, and provide the authority with satisfactory written proof that the violation has been corrected;        - Provide the authority with a written statement challenging the basis for terminating the use; or        - Provide a signed written agreement or a recorded written agreement with any other owner, tenant or person who has an interest in the use stating that the parties will not oppose the request to terminate the use.              The Act also provides that the owner of property subject to a notice of termination may not recover damages or compensation for lost profits, rental income, or diminution in value of the property because of the termination of the use.       You are instructed that you need not agree with any finding in this case concerning the sufficiency or service of the notice of termination.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The case law supporting sufficiency and service of a notice of termination is as follows: A notice of allowed use and a notice of termination are complete opposites. The former gives an applicant a property right, the latter takes away an applicant's property right. As a general rule, agencies have high standards with regard to notices which take away property rights. Adequate notice is usually a question of fact for which the applicant has the burden. Deadlines are generally strictly construed unless excusable neglect is shown. Administrative procedures in regard to notices are judicially reviewable, at the very least, for error of law. In all questions of law, agency action must be in conformance with regulations and state law, including the state constitution and the United States Constitution. The variances of the specific appeals may be cited therein, as major examples of lack of adequate notice or imperfection in the notices. The case law is as follows: 1. Howard de Paris v. Beer, 14 F.R.D. 675 (Dc. Ga. 1953) - service must be shown; 2. Karpowicz v. Division of Hous. of Dover, 200 N.J. Super. 193, 491 A.2d 1264 (App.Div. 1985) - notice must be fair, timely and adequate; 3. Boyle v. Anderson, 78 N.J. 226, 394 A.2d 1308 (1978) - notice must be to parties of record; 4. Tri-County Motor Coach v. Howard County, 273 Md. 378, 330 (1974) - notice must be specific; 5. Clawson Gardens Civic Imp. Comm. v. Srinivasan, 104 Ga. App. 138, 120 S.E.2d 442 (1961) - notice must advise of options and consequences of inaction; 6. Cal. Admin. Code, T 14, S 13055 - declaration may be filed within 30 days of service and receipt, unless extended for good cause shown; 7. Soremekun v. Thrifty Payless, Inc., 509 F.3d 978 (9th Cir.) (1995) - proof of mailing is prima facie evidence of receipt; 8. Cal. Gov. Code S 11513 - agency discretion may not be abused; 9. Cal. Gov. Code S 11513(d) - court may deny motions to accept late filings; 10. Mountain Medical Partners v. State of Calif., 228 Cal. Rptr. 3d 855 (2018) - public agency must provide written notice to person who may be adversely affected within 20 days after issuance or denial; 11. Bell v. State of Calif., 181 Cal. prompt: How should a jury apply Affirmative Defenseâ€”Implied Warranty of Habitability?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you find the defendant is liable to the plaintiff, you must then decide whether the defendant proved the affirmative defense of implied warranty of habitability. To prove the affirmative defense of implied warranty of habitability, the defendant must prove the following by a preponderance of the evidence:  1. The defendant was the landlord and the plaintiff was the tenant under a lease agreement and the plaintiff lived in the leased property as his or her residence; 2. The defendant leased the property to the plaintiff with an implied warranty that the property was habitable; and 3. The lease took place during a period in which the property was not habitable; and 4. As a result of the property not being habitable, the plaintiff suffered damages.   If you find that the defendant proved the affirmative defense of the implied warranty of habitability, then you must reduce the landlord/tenant damages by the amount of the damages that your find resulted for the breach of the implied warranty.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The following table provides a listing of some of the case law that supports the Affimative Defenseâ€”Implied Warranty of Habitability. The case law is from all states. State statutes and state regulations specifying the procedure for using the defense are not included. Please note that this does not constitute legal advice. You may wish to consult an attorney.     Defense    Citation    Summary       Implied Warranty of Habitability    Garcia v. Hochman, 45 Cal. Rptr. 3d 411 (Cal. Ct. App. 2006)    Also known as a warranty of habitability, this is the implied promise to provide safe and adequate housing. Housing that violates the building code or municipal health code is not considered adequate and fails to meet this warranty. Maintenance, building, and sanitation codes may require repairs such as the following: provide functioning electrical outlets, supply of hot water, sewer facilities, pest extermination, working and locking bathrooms, flooring, and adequate heat supply.     Implied Warranty of Habitability    Hitchcock v. Madsen, 105 Idaho 85, 665 P.2d 1287 (1983)    The implied warranty of habitability applies to all rental and residential tenancies except for transient stays such as at a motel, hotel, or boarding house. It should be borne in mind that the landlord-tenant relationship is essentially different from the relationship between a vendor and purchaser of goods. When a vendor sells goods to a purchaser, the entire consideration passes to the vendor at the time of the sale. On the other hand, under the lease or rental contract for property, the entire consideration is not paid at the time of the lease or rental, but only from time to time during the lease or rental in exchange for the right to exclusive possession and occupancy of the property for the period of time covered by the payment. It is this characteristic of the tenancy which permits a tenant to terminate the lease or rental agreement and quit the premises when the landlord has not repaired the premises due to the tenant's giving the landlord proper written notice of the need for repairs and a reasonable opportunity to make the repairs.     Implied Warranty of Habitability    Krolop v. Collins, 604 N.E.2d 1273 (Ind. Ct. App. 1992)    A landlord is obligated to repair conditions which cause the premises to be unsafe, unsanitary or unfit for human habitation. Under these circumstances, the tenant is entitled to a rebate in an amount proportional to the diminution in the value of the premises.     Implied Warranty of Habitability    Wilson v. prompt: How should a jury apply Affirmative Defenseâ€”Retaliatory Evictionâ€”Tenantâ€™s Complaint (Civ. Code, Â§ 1942.5)?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The defendant in this action claims it does not have a right to evict the plaintiff because the eviction is retaliatory. To establish a prima facie case of a retaliatory eviction, the defendant must prove each of the following elements by a preponderance of the evidence:        1. The defendant filed an action to obtain possession or recover possession of the premises within six months after the plaintiff either exercised the plaintiff's rights as a tenant or right to organize, started or increased rent strike payments, or initiated legal actions regarding the property or the defendant's duties as a landlord; and    2. The defendant knew that prior to the time the defendant filed the action for possession or recovered possession the plaintiff exercised the plaintiff's rights as a tenant or right to organize, started or increased rent strike payments, or initiated legal actions regarding the property or the defendant's duties as a landlord.        If the defendant establishes a prima facie case, the plaintiff may avoid the eviction action by proving a preponderance of the evidence that the defendant's eviction action was brought for reasons other than in retaliation.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"You must determine whether the plaintiff in the underlying action retaliated against the defendant in that action for a reason listed in the statute. If he or she did, then the plaintiff is using the eviction action for a retaliatory purpose. If the eviction action is being used for a retaliatory purpose, the defendant in that action may assert an affirmative defense.     This affirmative defense stops or \"bars\" the eviction action. However, this does not prevent the party who is retaliating from bringing an eviction action for another cause of action. Complained about the landlord, or has instituted or caused to be instituted any proceeding against the landlord, to recover damages or obtain other relief with respect to any alleged violation by the landlord of a landlord-tenant statute, ordinance or law; of any rule or regulation of a public utility; or of any building, housing or health code that affects health and safety.      f.  Filed a complaint with the Bureau of Real Estate about the landlord's failure to comply with requirements relating to state licensing and regulation of real estate licenses.      g.  Has filed proceedings seeking to enforce tenants' rights under the rental agreement between the parties.      h.  Organized or became a member of a tenants' organization that deals with tenants' housing issues, or has come to the aid of other tenants who have done any of the activities described above.            2. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Government Code Office of Administrative Law, California Code of Regulations Section 1603.63   Summary:  The affirmative defense of retaliatory eviction when a tenant is engaged in a legally protected activity is governed by a number of provisions in the Civil Code. The first is Section 1942.5(d), which states that \"it shall be an affirmative defense ... to an action for possession the evidence that the landlord has failed to satisfy heat, hot and cold water, gas or electricity, and has received three written complaints from the tenant or any labor organization that has as one of its members the tenant or an appropriate government agency that enforces habitability standards or to which the landlord has placed a copy of the relevant complaint, of the failure to satisfy one or more of such requirements.\" The affidavit of three such complaints and the landlord's failure to comply within a reasonable time is prima facie evidence of retaliatory eviction.    Section 1942.5(c) provides that it shall also be an affirmative defense to an action for possession if the landlord \"retaliates\" a tenant for engaging in \"legally protected activities,\" including but not limited to, \"(1) Joining, forming, or participating in a tenant organization; (2) Complaining to a landlord orally or in writing of a lack of repairs that are the landlord's legal responsibility to make; (3) Moving out because of a substandard dwelling; (4) Testifying or indicating an intention to testify in a civil or administrative proceeding concerning a landlord's failure to make legally required repairs; (5) Validly using the court's rent escrow procedure; (6) Filing a consumer complaint against a landlord based upon alleged violations of the California Consumer Legal Remedies Act ...\".     Section 1942.5(c) further provides that \"there shall be a presumption of retaliation if the tenant took one or more of the above listed action(s) not more than 180 days prior to the landlord's commencement of an action to recover possession.\"    According to Section 1942.5(e), in enacting the provisions of Section 1942.5, it was the Legislature's intention that the provision \"not apply to current or former tenants whose rent is found to be owing or who remain liable for damages to the premises.\"","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

This resource tells you about one of those defenses: \"Failure to Comply with Rent Control Ordinance/Tenant Protection Act.\" For example, if you want to move in a roommate and your landlord tries to evict you on grounds that moving in a roommate would increase the number of tenants, you could raise the defense of \"Failure to Comply with RCO/TPA.\"    Department of Consumer and Business Affairs\n\nSan Francisco has rent control for many residential rental properties. This allows tenants to remain in their housing for a longer period of time and helps maintain stable, affordable neighborhoods. Department of Consumer and Business Affairs","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Los Angeles has a rent control ordinance. Its official name is the Rent Stabilization Ordinance (\"RSO\"). The RSO restricts landlords in how much they can raise the rent and also regulates evictions of tenants. The RSO applies to most apartment buildings built before October 1, 1978.    The RSO has many rules. Many of these rules provide \"defenses\" for tenants. This means that tenants can use these rules to stop evictions brought by landlords. \"Failure to comply with the RSO\" is an example of such a defense.       \"Failure to comply with the RSO\" means that a landlord cannot evict you if the landlord is not obeying the RSO. For example, a landlord cannot evict you if you owe rent and the landlord has improperly raised your rent in violation of the RSO. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"An \"affirmative defense\" means that if you raise it, you have the burden of proving it. If you prove it, the defendant claims he or she is not legally responsible for the damage or injury.    Repair and deduct is an affirmative defense to a claim for the unpaid rent portion of a landlord's rental agreement. In other words, it is an affirmative defense that a landlord can raise against a claim for unpaid rent. To legally use the repair and deduct remedy, the tenant must prove, by a preponderance of the evidence:       - the tenant first gave the landlord written notice of the need for repairs;    - the repairs were necessary and the landlord refused or unreasonably delayed to make the repairs;    - the tenant made or contracted for the repairs; and    - the cost of the repairs was reasonable.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Virginia Consumer Protection Act exempts a person or household from the Act's provisions if the person or household is costumer of a business and complies with the repair and deduct procedure. A housing corporation under the Virginia Property Owners' Association Act is not a person or household and therefore the repair and deduct procedure does not apply, except for common areas which the housing corporation must treat as if the Act applies to them. (See Code of Virginia, Â§ 55-512.1).   Some other provisions regarding the repair and deduct procedure in the Virginia Consumer Protection Act are as follows: (1) If the business demands payment before the repair has been made it must have a bond posted with the state; (2) If the person or household fails to comply with the procedure he cannot assert a violation of the Act in a court proceeding except certain extraordinary circumstances exist; (3) If the person or household prevails in an action against the business, he may be entitled to recover attorneys' fees.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

The plaintiff may also argue that the tenant did not fulfill his legal obligations or is not entitled to use the repair and deduct option for some other reason.    The defendant then must demonstrate that he was entitled to use the repair and deduct option by meeting all the requirements. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under certain circumstances, tenants may deduct from rent money used to make necessary repairs. This is sometimes called the \"repair and deduct\" remedy. Most states permits this remedy in some form. Under Oregon law, a tenant is generally allowed to repair and deduct for \"repair and remedy\" obligations which are the responsibility of the landlord. This right arises from the nature of the tenancy and does not depend on any express agreement or contract provision. The tenant is limited in the amount he or she can deduct. A tenant may deduct a reasonable amount for repairs for each rental agreement, whether the agreement is periodic or for a set term. If the amount exceeds a limit, the tenant must notify the landlord. (The notice must describe the repairs and give an itemized receipt or a copy of the bill for the repairs.) Absent the notice, a tenant may not deduct more than $250 for repairs.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The legal standard for the Affirmative Defense-Victim of Abuse or Violence, Section 1161.3 of the Code of Civil Procedure, is that the tenant must be a victim of stalking or abuse, or the immediate family member of such victim that lived in the unit at the same time that the abuse or stalking occurred. The qualified third party may confirm the abuse or stalking to the landlord in writing.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

The law allows a victim of domestic violence, sexual assault, stalking, or human trafficking to use this as an affirmative defense to an unlawful detainer. \"Affirmative defense\" means you make a formal defense saying you have a good reason not to lose the case. For this law to apply to you, you must meet several requirements. They include having obtained a restraining order for the protection of the person or property of the victim, against the defendant. Or you must have entered into an agreement with the defendant, approved by a court, that prohibits the defendant from contacting the victim. The law also provides protections for retaliatory eviction.    For more information, you may go to HouseBill586.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under certain circumstances, a tenant may raise the affirmative defense of being a victim of domestic violence, sexual assault, or stalking to an unlawful detainer action for eviction based on a claim of nonpayment of rent. (Code Civ. Proc., Â§ 1161.3.) To do so, the tenant must show that: (1) the tenant has an order described in  Code of Civil Procedure section 1161.3, subdivision (c)(4)(B) against the alleged abuser or stalker; (2) the order terminates the party's right to occupy the rental unit; and (3) the landlord received written documentation establishing the existence of the order and the termination of the right to occupy. In an unlawful detainer action for eviction other than an action based on a claim of nonpayment of rent, a tenant who is a victim of domestic violence, sexual assault, or stalking may terminate a rental agreement upon written notice to the landlord. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under United States employment laws, it is unlawful for an employer to discriminate against a qualified individual on the basis of disability in regard to, among other things, job application procedures, hiring, advancement, or discharge of employees, employee compensation, job training, and other terms, conditions, and privileges of employment. An individual is \"disabled\" if he or she has a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities; has a record of such an impairment; or is regarded as having such an impairment.    Employment laws also prohibit discrimination against an individual because of a relationship or association with an individual with a disability. For example, an employer cannot discriminate against an employee who cares for a disabled family member.    To avoid contractor or subcontractor discrimination under Federal contracts, an employer must, among other requirements, take affirmative action to employ and advance in employment-qualified individuals with disabilities. If a contractor or subcontractor hires a qualified individual with a disability, the employer must accommodate the individual's disability in a way that enables the individual to perform the essential functions of the job.    Under the law, employees who can perform the essential functions of their jobs have a duty to cooperate with their employer's efforts to accommodate their disabilities. Cooperation means informing the employer about limitations related to the disability; answering the employer's questions; and providing medical or other information to help the employer determine if a reasonable accommodation would enable the employee to perform the essential functions of the job.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Code Â§ 12112 - Definition of discrimination with respect to employment Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities in employment. It applies to employers with 15 or more employees, including state and local governments. Employment agencies and labor organizations are also covered. To enforce the employment provisions, the Attorney General has adopted regulations providing standards and procedures. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) enforces these provisions and has adopted its own regulations providing standards and procedures. One of the specific purposes of the ADA is to prohibit discrimination in employment against a qualified individual on the basis of that individual's disability. For purposes of this chapter, the term \"discriminate\" and related terms mean - (1) not making reasonable accommodations to the known physical or mental limitations of an otherwise qualified individual with a disability, unless such covered entity can demonstrate that the accommodation would impose an undue hardship on the operation of the business of such covered entity; .... 29 U. S. Code Â§ 794 - Rehabilitation Act; employment A. prohibits the federal government, and programs that receive federal financial assistance, from discriminating against someone with a disability. It applies to all government agencies, employment, and to programs and activities that receive federal funds. The law also requires that federally funded programs and activities be accessible to persons with disabilities. The law is similar to the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and the courts often refer to decisions made under the ADA when interpreting the Rehabilitation Act. Court decisions about sections of the ADA other than employment can also be used to help interpret the Rehabilitation Act. This section prohibits discrimination in federally assisted programs and activities. It states, in part, that \"[n]o otherwise qualified individual with a disability . . . shall, solely by reason of her or his disability, be excluded from the participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance ....\" Present law prohibits discrimination against qualified individuals with handicaps in federally assisted programs. For the purpose of enforcing the prohibition, and implementing the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, the Attorney General is authorized to promulgate regulations, which may make exceptions regarding grants to religious organizations; and apply non-discrimination requirements to certain health or welfare agencies. The Act requires that federally assisted programs-voting, education, museums, medical care, transportation, parks, libraries, day care and others-be accessed by people with disabilities to the maximum extent possible. If buildings frequented by the public are altered, removed or newly constructed they must be accessible to persons with disabilities. Federal departments and agencies shall cooperate to the fullest extent practicable in effecting compliance with the requirements of any federally assisted program or activity with respect to which such department or agency exercises supervisory authority. B. prohibits public housing agencies from discriminating against qualified handicapped persons in all aspects of the housing programs they administer and requires such agencies to make reasonable accommodation of policies, practices, or procedures when such accommodation is necessary to afford such person equal opportunity to use and enjoy accommodations and facilities. The Department of Housing and Urban Development is responsible for enforcing this requirement. C. prohibits employers receiving federal funds from discriminating against a qualified person with a handicap in all aspects of employment including hiring, advancement or discharge from employment, compensation, job training opportunities, and other terms, conditions and privileges of employment. Those employers who received funds are required to make reasonable accommodation to the physical or mental limitations of the qualified individual unless doing so places an undue hardship on the employer. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is responsible for enforcing this requirement. Federal Contractors must also comply with the nondiscrimination and affirmative action provisions of Section 503 of the Rehabilitation Act. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Employment Discrimination Model Jury Instructions for the U.S. District Courts includes instruction number 24 addressing denial of requested accommodation. The instruction reads as follows: 24. Denial of Requested Accommodation

You have heard evidence that the plaintiff requested a certain accommodation to address the problem created by a disability, and the defendant denied that request.

That does not necessarily mean that the defendant failed to provide a reasonable accommodation or discriminated against the plaintiff because of a disability.  That denial is only one factor for you to consider in deciding whether the defendant provided a reasonable accommodation.  You should also consider other evidence related to the defendant's efforts to accommodate the plaintiff's disability.

You may find that the defendant discriminated against the plaintiff

- by failing to provide a reasonable accommodation, or
- by failing to engage in an interactive process in good faith.

To succeed, the plaintiff must show that a reasonable accommodation was available that would have allowed the plaintiff to perform the essential functions of the job, but the defendant failed to provide it.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Damages for Reasonable Rental Value?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The principle of damages for reasonable rental value is that if property is rented to a person, the owner is entitled to the reasonable rental value if there is a breach of contract. In other words, breaching party must pay to the owner the price that an owner could receive if the owner rented the property to another person.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When a person rents a property and vacates the premises prior to expiration of the lease, he is still liable for the rent until the lease expires. However, the person is only liable for the reasonable rental value of the premises. If the person can find another that is willing to rent the premises, he is still liable only for the reasonable rental value difference (i.e., the difference between what he agreed to pay under the lease and what the new tenant is willing to pay. For example, John was planning on moving back to his home state of Texas. He had been renting an apartment out of state and signed a lease agreement that would go into effect the month following the move. He found another that wanted to rent the apartment, but only at a lower price per month. John and the other tenant agreed on a price that was lower than the lease price. John was still liable to the rental company for the difference in the price. (If John had not found a new tenant, he would still have to pay the lease price.) The principle that a person is liable for only the reasonable rental value of the premises does not apply to houses or other accommodations held out for rent as a permanent residence.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When your property is damaged, some of the remedies are the same as when you suffer other kinds of losses. For example, you may be able to receive consequential damages, such as the loss of rental value. If you own a house or other property that you rent, you can recover the amount you would have earned in rent if the property cannot be rented because of damage caused by the breach.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In a personal injury case, damages for reasonable rental value may be available to a property owner if they had to rent a replacement vehicle while their property was being restored. They are meant to compensate the property owner for the cost of compensating the use of a replacement property. Reimbursement for the use of a replacement can also be obtained if the required repairs are so extensive that they take more time than it normally would to restore the property to its prior condition.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The principle of damages for reasonable rental value is set forth in the Restatement, Second, Torts, Section 929. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A trade secret is information that is valuable because it is secret. Trade secrets may include formulas, practices, processes, designs, instruments, patterns, or compilations of information. The key to a trade secret is that it is not generally known and that a business has taken actions that are reasonably calculated to keep it a secret. Trade secrets give companies a competitive advantage. Removing or using them without permission can create unfair competition.    Misappropriation of trade secrets can occur when someone copies the secret or acquires it in a way that is considered improper (i.e., through theft, bribery, misrepresentation, breach or inducement of a breach of duty to maintain secrecy, or espionage).    Trade secret laws differ from one jurisdiction to another. The Uniform Trade Secrets Act has been adopted in many states. It protects trade secrets from being disclosed to outsiders or used by competitors. The Economic Espionage Act is a federal law that prohibits corporate espionage and the theft of trade secrets for the benefit of a foreign government. It is based on a treaty with the other countries and is used to promote international cooperation against trade secret theft.    The Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016 amends United States federal law to add a private civil cause of action for trade secret misappropriation. This gives trade secret owners the right to sue in Federal District Court. Trade secret owners will still have the option of suing under State trade secret law.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Trade Secret Defined    {[}Name of defendant{]} is charged with misappropriating a trade secret owned by {[}name of plaintiff{]}.     A trade secret is information, including a formula, pattern, compilation, program, device, method, technique or process, that:           1. derives independent economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to, and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by, other persons who can obtain economic value from its disclosure or use, and     2. is the subject of efforts to maintain its secrecy that are reasonable under the circumstances.        For the information here involved, you must decide if {[}name of plaintiff{]} has made reasonable efforts under the circumstances to maintain its secrecy. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under the Uniform Trade Secrets Act, the person claiming that there was a trade secret must show that the owner of the trade secret took reasonable efforts to keep it secret. What is reasonable will depend on the value of the trade secret and the parties involved. Reduced protection may be adequate in some instances. For example, employers have less responsibility to maintain secrets than do employees because some disclosure to employees is necessary. A partial list of examples of reasonable efforts to maintain secrecy includes        - Labeling the information \"secret\" or as \"confidential\";    - Having employees with access to trade secrets sign confidentiality agreements or requests and willing to maintain secrecy;    - Locking up or restricting access to trade secrets;    - Restricting access to trade secrets, including computer firewalls and password protected files, to only those who need to know;     - Keeping copies or disseminating only copies that show confidential status; and    - Requiring nondisclosure agreements of third parties.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Under the law, a trade secret must be subject to efforts that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain its secrecy. These efforts do not have to be overly expensive or elaborate. Steps companies have taken to keep information secret in previous litigation are available online. Examples include limiting access to information only to those who have a need to know, labeling documents as confidential, requiring visitors to sign in, using passwords for computer access, locking away items, discussing confidential matters only behind closed doors, disposing of documents carefully, requiring employees to sign confidentiality agreements, and conducting exit interviews with departing employees regarding trade secrets.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are the elements of the Misappropriation by Acquisition?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"It is generally illegal to take property that belongs to another person and use or enjoy it, even when you have the good intent of trying to make things better - as demonstrated in these elements of misappropriation: Once a person(s) takes or obtains another person's property,        - the conversion is complete and the person(s) no longer has to subsequently intend to deprive the other of the use of the property,     - the person(s) is required to return the property or compensate its owner,     - it is not a defense if the owner of the property is not deprived of its use; it is sufficient if the owner is deprived temporarily of possession or enjoyment of the property,     - intent with respect to conversion means to exercise domination over another's property, and     - when the person converts the property to his own use, the intent is presumed.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Because a misappropriation by acquisition involves the obtaining of title or possession by some sort of conduct other than force or intimidation, the key element which distinguishes it from a robbery or theft is that it involves a covert acquisition. In some cases this involves tricking a person into turning over title or possession. For example, con-men use sleight-of-hand to trick a person into turning over something of value. Other forms include getting a person to sign a document, such as a deed, that transfer title to the perpetrator, or getting a bank to send a person's money to a different destination by impersonating the person. The key difference is that in these cases a person is generally \"giving\" the thing to be misappropriated, rather than being forced or intimidated into giving it.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If a person misappropriates (steals) material, nonpublic information in breach of a duty of confidentiality owed to the source of the information and then uses or discloses that information for securities trading purposes, that person is also liable to prosecution for insider trading. Other clients of the lawyer might want to buy stock in the division, if they knew of the impending sale.  The lawyer has a duty to keep the matter confidential, even if not formally retained by the client.  If the lawyer or someone the lawyer tips off trades on the nonpublic information, those persons may be liable for insider trading. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The trade secret misappropriation act provides in part: \"A person misappropriates a trade secret if, without the express or implied consent of the owner thereof, the person: (a) Discloses or uses another's trade secret, which the person: (1) Used improper means to acquire; or (2) At the time of disclosure or use, knew or had reason to know that the trade secret was acquired by accident or mistake or under circumstances that gave rise to a duty to maintain its secrecy or limit its use[.]\" You will not find case law supporting the act until after the act is passed.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Misappropriation Principle provides: \"Revenue shall be recognized when it is realized or realizable and earned. Realization occurs when products or services are exchanged for cash or claims to cash. A product or service is considered to be earned when the entity has substantially accomplished what it must do to be entitled to the benefits represented by the product or service. Two criteria normally must be met before revenue is recognized. The first is that the revenue is realized or realizable. Generally, revenue is realizable if there is a reasonable assurance of the payment to the entity, in accordance with the sales contract. The second is that the revenue is earned. Revenue is earned when the entity has substantially accomplished what it must do to be entitled to the benefits represented by the revenue.\"","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA) was promulgated by the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws with the goal of providing uniformity of law among the several states. Instead of passing \"laws,\" the individual states pass \"enabling legislation\" which enacts the specific uniform act into their state's statutory code. Although the UTSA draft and all of the adopted versions are very similar, some of the \"enabling legislation\" does vary from state to state with regards to word usage and section numbering. As of January 2015, the most recent version of the UTSA has been enacted in 46 states, the District of Columbia, Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Massachusetts and New York are the two states which have not adopted the UTSA. Once enacted by a state, the provisions of the UTSA replace any conflicting state trade secret laws. The provisions of the original UTSA cover the following: relations to other laws, definitions, actual or threatened misappropriation, remedies, attorney's fees, and effective date.  The remedies under the UTSA consist of injunctive relief, damages, and attorney's fees. Inappropriate threat of an action under the UTSA can also be enjoined.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A trade secret is a secret device or technique used by a company in manufacturing its products. Trade secrets are a type of intellectual property. Like other types of intellectual property, trade secrets are valuable assets. An important part of protecting the value of trade secrets is to have remedies available if someone misappropriates the trade secret. You have remedies under both federal and state law. By law, remedies can include either monetary damages or an injunction. Monetary damages compensate you for your loss of money. They cannot undo the fact that the offender used the trade secret. Injunctions prohibit certain actions. An injunction can keep a person or company from using a trade secret or selling a product that results from use of that trade secret.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When a public agency prepares plans and specifications for a construction project, the plans and specifications become a contract between the agency and the contractor. If anything in the plans or specifications differs from the actual conditions at the construction site, the agency will issue a \"change order.\" This tells the contractor what changes to make to the contracted work. Once the change order is signed, it becomes part of the contract.    The contractor may also do some extra work that the agency did not originally plan for. To get paid for the work, the contractor must get a work order from the agency that states the extra work that is to be done.    If the contractor believes the work order is for work different from the contract work, he or she may file a claim against the agency for \"changed work.\" If the contractor believes the work order is for work above and beyond what he or she has contracted to do, the claim against the agency is for \"extra work.\"","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How is Waiver of Written Approval or Notice Requirements for Changed or Additional Work explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"To prove your breach of contract claim, you will need to prove each of the following elements: that there was a valid contract, that you did what the contract required you to do, and that the defendant did not do what the contract required the defendant to do.    The contract between you and the defendant includes various requirements.  Among others, the contract requires that if you want to make a change or add something to the work described in the contract, you must first get the defendant's written approval or give the defendant written notice within seven days after you make the change or add something.  This requirement is satisfied if the defendant signs a specific form provided in the contract.    If you make changes or add work without the defendant's written approval or without giving the defendant written notice, the contract says that the defendant \"waive[s]\" or gives up its right to require that you obtain the defendant's approval or give the defendant notice.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Waiver of Written Approval or Notice Requirements for Changed or Additional Work is a standard provision in contracts between contractors and owners. It is generally included in contracts based on the American Institute of Architects' (AIA) standard contract documents. This provision explains when you are deemed to have waived your right to a requirement set forth in the contract to receive either a written approval or a written notice. For example, it is set forth in the contract that all change orders must be signed by you and the contractor. If you accepted a change order that the parties had not signed, then you would be deemed to have ''waived'' the requirement that change orders be signed. In this example, the waiver of notice or approval is provided because you accepted a change and if you were upset later you could have objected at the time.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When is a waiver of the requirement of written approval or notice for changed or additional work effective? [Use this instruction in a case that includes contract damages. Otherwise, delete this instruction.]","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A construction contract may contain a clause stating that the contractor cannot do additional work or change the work without a prior written approval from the owner. If that is the case, the clause also may provide that any waiver of the written approval must be express.       You claim that there is a clause in your contract requiring the owner's prior written approval of any additional work or change, and that because you do not have this written approval, you cannot recover for the additional work or change. The other party claims that there is evidence that you waived the requirement of the owner's prior written approval of the additional work or change.    To prove waiver of a writing requirement, the other party must prove all of the following by a preponderance of the evidence:       1. You knew of your right to require the owner's prior written approval;     2. You voluntarily gave up that right; and       3. You intended to give up that right.       You should only find that the writing requirement was waived if the other party has satisfied all three of these requirements.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When can the requirement for a written approval or certain notices be waived? Certain requirements in your contract that certain approvals or certain notices must be in writing can be waived. For example, if you accept a higher quality product than was required by contract and you do not object, the requirement that you must give written approval to the higher quality product may be waived. In order to waive a requirement for a written approval or notice, the parties must:        - Knowingly give up the requirement, or    - Act in a way that is inconsistent with the requirement and the other party relies on the inconsistency to his detriment.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: How is Ownerâ€™s Damages for Breach of Construction Contractâ€”Work Does Not Conform to Contract explained to the jury?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"In cases in which a plaintiff alleges a breach of contract resulting in damages to real property, the plaintiff may recover the reasonable value of the work done minus any diminution in value of the property caused by defects. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"When a construction contract is breached, generally a property owner may recover       - the difference between the value of the property with the improvements as promised and the value of the property with the improvements as constructed; or    - the reasonable cost of repair or completion of the improvements.       In this case, you may award damages to the plaintiff in the amount that you find reasonable.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"May the owner recover damages for breach of the construction contract even though the signed contract contains a warranty disallowing such recovery? The contract in this case contained a warranty. The warranty stated that the owner could not recover damages for breach of the contract because the contractor promised that the work under the contract would conform to the plans and specifications and that any failure to conform would be corrected. The warranty stated that it survived acceptance of the work.    Does this type of warranty prevent the owner from recovering damages for breach of the contract? We find no case in Washington addressing whether this type of warranty prevents the owner from recovering damages for breach of a construction contract. For that reason, we turn to the authority in other jurisdictions.    An analagous issue that several jurisdictions have addressed is whether a contractor may disavow any liability for consequential damages for a breach of contract. We have relied on such cases in the past when interpreting contracts of service. Generally, courts have upheld such waivers, but have construed them narrowly to exclude only those damages that could not be expected in light of the circumstances of the parties at the time of contracting. See, e.g., Netcraft Corp. v. Flame Tech, Inc., 126 Wash. App. 584, 594, 109 P.3d 232 (2005) (in the absence of any other construction, narrowly construing a limitation of liability under a service contract).    Similarly, a majority of courts that have considered a warranty disallowing damages for breach of a construction contract have concluded that the warranty bars remedies other than allowing the owner to compel the work or have the contractor do the work at its expense. See Gleeson v. Kinslow Bros. Logging Co., 289 Or. 1, 609 P.2d 397, 404 (1980) (listing cases supporting this view); cf. Elizabeth T. Sullivan, Annotation, Contractor's Liability Under Building Contract When Building Does Not Conform to Plans and Specifications, 12 A.L.R. 4th 38 (1982) (citing cases holding that a nonconforming building is a breach of contract even if it is a substantial performance).    We agree that the primary remedy available to an owner under this type of warranty is to compel the contractor to do the work or have the contractor do the work. We also conclude, however, that resale is a remedy in equity to be ordered at the discretion of the court.        Instruction    The contractor has a warranty that the work under the contract will conform to the plans and specifications and that any failure to conform will be corrected. If you find that the work or improvements constructed by the contractor do not conform to the plans and specifications, the court may order that the deficiency be corrected by the contractor at the contractor's expense. Once the cost of correcting any deficiency is determined, the court will specify a further date for completion of the work, which must be a reasonably sufficient period of time after the court's determination.     When the work is not completed as ordered by the court, the owner may obtain the work at the contractor's expense. If the owner obtains the work, the contractor is liable in damages for any additional expense reasonably incurred by the owner. If the court finds that it is impractical to have the work done by the contractor, the owner may obtain the work from someone else.    An owner has a duty to mitigate damages, including any reasonable expense involved in obtaining work done by the contractor or another.        No automatic recovery of lost profit    You should not find for the owner on the ground that the work failed to conform to the contract simply because the work was not done by the contractor. To recover on this ground, the owner must prove all the elements necessary to recover damages. Specifically, nothing herein requires automatic recovery of lost profit.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The Breach of Contract section of the Minnesota Jury Instruction Guide explains Owner's Damages for Breach of Construction Contract-Failure to Complete Work to the jury. The instruction is as follows:  OWNER'S DAMAGES FOR BREACH OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACT - FAILURE TO COMPLETE WORK When a contract to construct, repair, and improve land is breached by noncompliance, the owner may recover damages. The measure of damages for the contractor's failure to complete the work or his default is the difference between the contract price and the reasonable cost of completing the job in accordance with the contract or the reasonable value of the work, services, and materials accepted by the owner under the contract, whichever is the less. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Liquidated damages are damages agreed upon in advance for a specific breach. Delaware law allows owners of construction contracts to recover liquidated damages for breach of contract due to delay, provided certain conditions are met. Liquidated damages for breach of construction contract are usually included in the contract to compensate the owner for the extra time and money they will have to spend finding an alternate completion of the construction job. The contract will usually describe the amount of each liquidated damage and when it will be incurred.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Owners commonly include a provision in their contracts with the builder called a \"liquidated damages\" provision. This provision sets a financial penalty against the builder for failing to complete the work on time. This penalty is a predetermined sum of money specified in the contract that the builder must pay if it does not perform its part of the contract on time.    For example, if you contract with a builder for a new house that is to be finished on April 1 and the builder does not finish by that date, he or she must pay you, as specified in the contract, a certain amount of money for each day or week that completion is delayed or a flat sum of money if it is not finished by the scheduled date.    Liquidated damages are designed to compensate owners for anticipated harm or loss that may be caused by delay in the performance of a contract. Liquidated damages are enforceable only if they are a reasonable estimate of what the owner is actually likely to lose because of the delay. If they constitute a penalty rather than compensation for the owner's injury, they are not enforceable.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Jurisdiction varies on damages for a breach of construction contract. The following instruction is a general statement of damages for a breach as decided by a jury. Modification may be needed to fit the circumstances of your case and law of your jurisdiction.     ------------------------------------------   CONTRACTOR'S DAMAGES FOR BREACH OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACT-CHANGE ORDERS/EXTRA WORK   If the contract between ____________________ and ____________________ was not fully performed by the parties, then you must determine the amount of money that is necessary to put the party who was not at fault in the position it would have been in if the contract had been fully performed. In other words, you must determine the amount of money that party would have received if the contract had been fully performed as agreed upon by the parties.    In the event that a party performing the contract does extra work or additional work on the project, that party is entitled to be compensated for that extra work or additional work, as long as such work was authorized and did not serve to delay the project. If the contract was not fully performed because such extra work or additional work was not compensated, the party performing the work is entitled to such compensation as well as any additional damages to which he may be entitled.    If the party performing the contract stops performing the work before it is finished because of the other party's breach of contract, and it is later agreed to return to perform the work, the party may be entitled to additional money to cover increased costs to be incurred as a result of greater price of labor or materials, increased labor costs, changed conditions, changed labor force and availability of materials, changed material costs, changed availability of skilled workmen, changed machinery costs, changed social or economic conditions, or changed market conditions.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These instructions are for a contract case, not a criminal case. Your job is to decide whether the plaintiff has proven its case against the defendant by the greater weight of the evidence. The plaintiff has the burden of proof. The greater weight of the evidence means the amount of credible evidence that is enough to make a person believe that a proposition is more likely true than not true. In determining if the plaintiff has met this burden, you should compare the evidence which supports the proposition to the evidence which is opposed to it.    In this case the parties have stipulated that an oral contract existed between them. The plaintiff claims that the defendant breached the oral contract by not paying full compensation for extra work that was approved by the defendant before the extra work was performed or completed.     The plaintiff asks you to award damages for this breach. If you find that the plaintiff has proven that the defendant breached the oral contract, then you may award damages in an amount that will compensate the plaintiff for the loss it sustained as a direct result of the defendant's breach. A claimant is not entitled to recover damages for loss that the claimant could have avoided without undue risk, burden or humiliation.     The plaintiff must prove that the damages it seeks were sustained as a natural and probable consequence of the breach or were within the contemplation of the parties at the time the contract was made. In computing damages, you should consider whether the defendant has received any benefits from the extra work.     RANDOLPH COUNTY JURY INSTRUCTION COMMITTEE ","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The contractor may be entitled to damages if the owner increases the contractor's cost of performing under the contract, including cost of performing additional work authorized by a change order, or extra work. The measure of the contractor's recovery for breach of the change order or extra work provisions of the contract depends on whether the contract was a lump sum contract or a unit price contract. Under a lump sum contract, the contractor's damages are generally based on the cost of the additional work as compared to the contract price. prompt: How should a jury apply Contractorâ€™s Damages for Abandoned Construction Contractâ€”Quantum Meruit Recovery?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If a contract is abandoned, you may be entitled to recover the reasonable value of the contractor's labor and materials actually used in the work.     In an abandoned construction contract, an attempt should be made to adjust the contract price in accordance with the extent to which the work was performed or accepted. If the contract price is not adjusted by a reasonable credit or allowance in view of the partial performance of the contract, the contractor is entitled to recover the reasonable value of the labor and materials actually used in the work. You should find the reasonable cost of the work of improvements performed under the contract or the reasonable value on the date of abandonment of the work when completed to the extent cemented and accepted or retained under the contract, as the case may be, and deduct from such amount the contract price totaled for the quantity contained in the contract work to the extent that the work is performed or done.
