{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A contract is a promise or set of promises that the law will enforce. When one of the parties to a contract does not perform as promised under the contract, it is called a breach of contract. A party injured by another's breach of contract can generally recover money damages. The purpose of damages is to award to the injured party an amount of money that will, as nearly as possible, put the injured party in as good a position as he or she would have been in had the contract been performed.    The owner breached the contract before the contractor completed the contract work. Under these circumstances, the contractor cannot recover for the contract work it did not perform. However, the contractor may recover under a quantum meruit theory for contract work it did perform if (a) the owner requested the work, (b) the work was accepted by the owner, (c) the contractor performed the work in good faith, (d) the contractor did not relinquish its rights under the contract, and (e) the amount to be paid for the work under the contract is uncertain. In order for the contractor to recover under a quantum meruit theory, you must find that all these elements are present.    Quantum meruit is Latin for \"as much as he deserved.\" Quantum meruit allows recovery of the reasonable value of goods or services furnished.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"A contractor who has abandoned a construction contract may be entitled to recover the value of the work done before the abandonment. Quantifying the value of the work done before the abandonment involves resolving two issues. The first issue is whether to value the work done before the abandonment using the contract price, adjusted for credit that the non-breaching party is entitled to, or to use the value of the work as proven by the contractor.    The contract price is the amount the contractor agreed to be paid; this number is on page 3 of the contract. If you use the contract price, you must deduct any amounts the owner has already paid to the contractor for the work done before abandonment. You may also deduct amounts that represent the ownerâ€™s damages for delay and any diminution in value of the ownerâ€™s property resulting from the work done before the abandonment. Alternatively, you may determine the value of the work done before abandonment by determining the reasonable value of the work as proven by the contractor. The reasonable value of the work is the value of the work agreed to be done by the contract shown by other work comparable to that agreed to be done by the contract.    The second issue is whether an amount should be deducted from the amount allowed to the contractor for damage due to the contractor's failure to complete the contract. For example, if a contractor abandoned a construction contract before some work, the contract may allow a property owner to employ someone else to complete the contract. If the owner did this, it may have cost less to employ someone else than to have the contractor complete the contract. Thus, the owner may be entitled to a credit for the difference between what it cost the owner to have the work completed and the contract price. The reasonable cost of having the remaining work completed is the amount agreed to by the parties or, if they were unable to agree, the amount found by the jury or determined by the court (depending on whether the contract between the owner and the new contractor was a written contract or an oral contract).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is the principle of Contractorâ€™s Damages for Breach of Construction Contractâ€”Owner-Caused Delay or Acceleration?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The owner of a construction project sometimes causes delays or accelerates the contractor's work. For instance, the owner may not deliver drawings or permit access to the site on schedule or may order the work to be done faster than originally scheduled.  If these happen and the contractor has claims for damages, the law generally follows the principles described below. The contractor's contract with the owner may limit or change these principles.  Delays. The court will generally distinguish between two types of delay when a case goes to trial: excusable or nonexcusable. Excusable delay is a delay for which the contractor is not responsible. Nonexcusable delay is a delay for which the contractor is responsible and includes delays caused by the contractor. Compensation for excusable delay may be granted if the contractor so requests and meets certain requirements. Compensation for nonexcusable delay is usually denied.  Acceleration. After a delay, the contractor may be able to accelerate the work to meet the contract completion date. And, the owner may order the work to be accelerated. Acceleration can include hiring more workers, ordering more materials, and working overtime or temporarily adding a second shift. Acceleration can increase the costs to the contractor; the owner may be responsible for these increased costs.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Construction contractors who sue for breach of contract often claim they are entitled to money damages because the owner delayed termination of the contract. Delays and acceleration claims are especially difficult to prove because they require negotiations with the plaintiff regarding the contract price. If there were existing escalator provisions for delays, they are part of the contract and, presumably, appropriately compensate each party for certain types of delays. For other delays, the contractor must show a breach of contract and resulting damages. The most commonly recognized damages are direct damages (costs of acceleration) and consequential damages (loss profits).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The owner of a building contract has certain rights under the contract including the right to require any work of extra work specified by the contract and to make modifications in the plans and specifications. If the owner exercises any of these rights under the contract, the owner will not be liable for breach of contract. There are times, however, when the owner executes its rights under the contract in an unreasonable manner. When this occurs, the owner may be liable for breach of contract for owner's actions even if authorized by contract. There are several reasons the owner's actions may be unreasonable. For example, it is possible for the owner to have an actual and a contractual right to require a modification of the work. The owner has the right under contract but not as a prudent project manager to require such a modification. Thus, if the owner exercises the right it has under contract but not the actual right, it may be liable for breach of contract. It is also possible for the owner to execute its rights under contract in a negligent manner. When this occurs, the owner's actions may be unreasonable and the owner may be liable.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If an owner causes delay to or acceleration of a construction project, the contractor must mitigate the damages. This means the contractor must take reasonable steps to avoid or reduce the additional costs caused by the owner's actions. The contractor may contract with others or use its own work force to try to get back on schedule. However, even if the contractor has mitigated its damages, it is not entitled to compensation if it eventually completes the project late because of causes unrelated to the owner's delay. For example, if the owner delays construction by 10 days, but the project is eventually completed 30 days late, the contractor may only be entitled to compensation for the 10 days cause by the owner.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Summary of Instruction 2446 is as follows: Sometimes there can be a decrease in productivity, that is, a decrease in the amount of work done per unit of input, or loss of efficiency, during the construction project. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"These instructions relate to a counterclaim or cross-claim for damages for breach of a construction contract. If you decide for the plaintiff on its claim for damages, you need not reach the defendant's counterclaim or cross-claim. For the defendant to prevail on the claim, the burden of proof is on the defendant. A claimant has the burden of proving his case by a preponderance of the evidence. This means that you must be persuaded, considering all the evidence in the case, that the claimant's contention is more probably true than not true.    Inefficiency.  Inefficiency means waste of time, effort or material, including situations where equipment or labor that is paid for is not used or underused. Inefficiency might occur when a period of down-time or waiting follows periods of work or overwork, or when a period of slow-down follows a period of work at a fast pace.    It is possible to prove inefficiency damages using industry standards or rules of thumb, rather than actual costs. If plaintiff shows that the inefficiency damage meets its burden, the defendant may challenge the appropriateness of those inefficiency damages based on other evidence, such as proof of higher than average actual efficiency.    If one employee or category is out of balance compared to another, this will not necessarily prove inefficiency. Inefficiency occurs when actual output over a given time period is less than it would have been under a more balanced arrangement.    If you find that the claimant has proved inefficiency, you must award damages for inefficiency only to the extent that the claimant has not been compensated for inefficiency in other damage categories.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

A \"qualifying latent construction defect\" is a defect in the design, materials, or workmanship for which a builder is liable under the law, which defect causes damage to any of the following:       - the building structure of a \"new residential housing construction\" as defined by Section 896 of the Civil Code; or    - the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, electrical, and other systems that are part of the new residential housing construction and which serve the building structure; or       - in the case of common areas, the portions of a \"common interest development\" as defined in Section 1351 of the Civil Code, which are part of the building structure or the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, electrical, or other systems.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

If a defendant claims the lawsuit is barred by the statute of limitations, it is an affirmative defense. A statute of limitations may be counted from the date the plaintiff knew or should have known of the problem.. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Your job as a jury is to decide whether the plaintiff proved every essential part of their case by a preponderance of the evidence. This means that you must be convinced, based on the evidence presented to you, that it is more likely than not that each essential part of the complaint is true. If you decide that the plaintiff failed to prove any essential part of the complaint by a preponderance of the evidence, you must find in favor of the defendant.    The defendant contends that the complaint is barred by a time limit contained in the law, called a statute of limitations. A statute of limitations requires a claim in a lawsuit to be filed within a specific time period. When the specific time period has passed, the claim is said to be barred.    Under the law, if you decide the defendant has established that the claim in the complaint is barred, then your verdict should be in favor of the defendant. However, the law recognizes certain exceptions to a statute of limitations. One of these exceptions contains a specific time limit for bringing an action based on latent construction defect. For purposes of this exception, a latent defect is defined as a defect in a building that could not be discovered by reasonable inspection before the expiration of the one-year statute of limitation for injury to property. The exception provides that an action based on a latent construction defect must be commenced within 10 years after the substantial completion of the improvement to real property, not including additions or alterations that individually cost more than 5 percent of the original contract price or $25,000, whichever is less, or which increase the total floor area of the structure by more than 10 percent of the original floor area, whichever is less. The exception also allows a tolling of the statute of limitations during any period in which the damage was not discovered and could not reasonably have been discovered.    In the present case, the defendant in this action is asserting the exception to the statute of limitations for latent construction defect. If you decide that the time limit for bringing an action based on a latent construction defect applies and, therefore, bars the complaint, your verdict should be for the defendant.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}
